revision.comment: /* Dar es Salaam campus */
revision.text:
{{Infobox University |name = Kampala International University |image = |motto = Exploring the Heights{{fact|date=May 2017}} |established = 2001 |type = [[Private university|Private]] |vice_chancellor = Peter. K. Tibenderana |city = [[Kampala]] |country = [[Uganda]] |students = 12,000+ |staff = 250+ |campus = Main Campus, [[Urban area|Urban]]
Western Campus, [[Rural]] |website = {{URL|http://www.kiu.ac.ug/|Kampala International University}} }} '''Kampala International University''' (KIU) is a private multi-campus university in [[Uganda]]. ==Location== KIU has its main campus at [[Kansanga]], a location in [[Makindye Division]] in the south-eastern part of [[Kampala]], Uganda's capital and largest city. The campus is approximately {{convert|7|km|mi}} south-east of Kampala's central business district, along the road to [[Ggaba]]. The coordinates of the campus are 0°17'41.0"N, 32°36'13.0"E (Latitude:0.294722; Longitude:32.603611).{{cite web | publisher=[[Google|Google Maps]] | url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/0%C2%B017'41.0%22N+32%C2%B036'13.0%22E/@0.2950477,32.6026165,16z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x0 | title=Location of Kampala International University Main Campus At Google Maps | last=Google | accessdate=15 July 2014}} KIU's second campus is located in [[Ishaka]] in [[Bushenyi District]], approximately {{convert|360|km|mi}}, by road, south-west of Kampala.{{cite web | publisher=Globefeed.com | accessdate=15 July 2014 | title=Map Showing Kampala And Ishaka With Distance Marker | url=http://distancecalculator.globefeed.com/Uganda_Distance_Result.asp?fromplace=Ishaka%20(Bushenyi)&toplace=Kampala%20()&fromlat=-0.5430556&tolat=0.3155556&fromlng=30.1369444&tolng=32.5655556}} KIU maintains a third campus, the KIU Dar es Salaam Constituent College, in [[Dar es Salaam]], [[Tanzania]]. ==History== KIU was founded in 2001. It received its university charter in March 2009.{{cite web | url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/20/674771 | title=KIU Didn't Start Climbing The Tree From The Top | publisher=[[New Vision]] | date=17 March 2009 | accessdate=15 July 2014b | first=Karooro | last=Okurut | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140722125501/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/20/674771 | archivedate=22 July 2014 | df= }} ==Academic colleges, schools, and institutes== ===Main campus=== KIU's main campus has four constituent colleges and four schools: "Kampala International University Prospectus 2016". Kiu.ac.tz/prospectus, 2016 # College of Education, Open and Distance Learning # College of Computing and Information Technology # College of Higher Degrees and Research # College of Professional and Extramural Studies # School of Law # School of Economics and Management # School of Engineering and Applied Sciences # School of Humanities This is the largest of the three campuses, hosting more than 7,000 students and over 300 academic staff.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ===Western campus=== {{main|Kampala International University School of Health Sciences}} This campus houses over 5,000 students supervised by over 200 academic staff. Certificate, diploma, undergraduate, and postgraduate programs are offered at this campus. It is predominantly a science-based institution. The School of Health Sciences is located on the western campus. The school is one of Uganda's seven medical schools, and it was the first privately owned medical school in the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/583950|title=KIU Medical School Accredited|publisher=[[New Vision]]|date=29 August 2007|accessdate=16 July 2014|first=Carol|last=Natukunda|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140722161048/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/583950|archivedate=22 July 2014|df=}} The school offers programmes in medicine, dentistry, nursing, medical laboratory technology, education, business, and management and information technology. The school has a [[teaching hospital]] with a bed capacity of 1,200.{{cite web| url=http://www.observer.ug/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=11088%3Abasajjabalaba-to-build-medical-school-in-kenya&Itemid=96|title=Basajjabalaba To Build Medical School In Kenya|first=Wilber|date=28 November 2010| last=Muhwezi|accessdate=16 July 2014|publisher=[[The Observer (Uganda)]]}}{{cite web|accessdate=16 July 2014|url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/30/689387|title=Basajja Given USh4 Billion for Hospital|publisher=[[New Vision]]|date=27 July 2009|last=Ahimbisibwe|first=Chris|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140722153140/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/30/689387|archivedate=22 July 2014|df=}} ===Dar es Salaam campus=== {{main|Kampala International University In Tanzania}} This campus is housed on {{convert|100|acre|ha}} in the Gongolamboto area in [[Ilala District]], along Pugu Road. The campus is approximately {{convert|7|km|mi}} from [[Julius Nyerere International Airport]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thecitizen.co.tz/News/-/1840392/1845730/-/exkjyuz/-/index.html|title=TCU Suspends Postgraduate Courses At KIUT |last=The Citizen|first=Reporter|date=7 May 2013|accessdate=16 July 2014|publisher=[[Mwananchi Communications|The Citizen]] (Tanzania)}} ==2013 government investigation== In 2013, the Ugandan National Council for Higher Education (NCHE) began an investigation into whether the 42 [[Doctorate of Philosophy|Doctorates of Philosophy]] (PhDs) awarded by KIU up to that time had met NCHE's requirements. At the end of the investigation in November 2013, NCHE declared that the PhDs were legitimate.{{cite web|title=NCHE Okays KIU PhDs| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/NCHE-okays-KIU-PhDs/-/688334/2071064/-/36tnjhz/-/index.html|first=Richard|last=Wanambwa| date=13 November 2013|accessdate=16 July 2014|publisher=[[Daily Monitor]]}} ==Photos== * [https://www.flickr.com/photos/7192386@N06/3940464376/ Photo of KIU Western Campus Main Building] ==See also== * [[Education in Uganda]] * [[List of universities in Uganda]] * [[List of university leaders in Uganda]] * [[List of medical schools in Uganda]] * [[List of business schools in Uganda]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.kiu.ac.ug Kampala International University Homepage] * [http://www.kiu.ac.tz Kampala International University In Tanzania] * [http://www.monitor.co.ug/Magazines/HomesandProperty/Know-your-hood---Kansanga/-/689858/1613118/-/lrtxxgz/-/index.html Know Your Hood : Kansanga, This Sprawling Neighbourhood Is The Hub For University Students] {{coord|00|17|41|N|32|36|13|E|display=title}} {{Kampala District}} [[Category:Universities and colleges in Uganda]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2001]] [[Category:Education in Kampala]] [[Category:Makindye Division]]

revision.comment: /* Developing individual leaders */
revision.text:
{{multiple issues|{{more citations needed|date=July 2014}} {{weasel|date=December 2016}}}} '''Leadership development''' expands the capacity of individuals to perform in [[leadership]] roles within organizations. Leadership roles are those that facilitate execution of a company’s [[business strategy|strategy]] through building alignment, winning [[mindshare]] and growing the capabilities of others. Leadership roles may be formal, with the corresponding authority to make decisions and take responsibility, or they may be informal roles with little official authority (e.g., a member of a [[team]] who influences team engagement, purpose and direction; a lateral peer who must listen and negotiate through influence).<ref>''How to Attack the Business Skills Mismatch'', [http://www.clomedia.com Chief Learning Officer Magazine], by Rommin Adl (August 2013)</ref>
Leadership development is thought to be key to business success. A study by the [[Center for Creative Leadership]] holds that 65 percent of companies with mature leadership development programs drove improved business results as compared to 6 percent of companies without such a program. Similarly, 86% of companies with leadership development programs responded rapidly to changing market conditions whereas only 52% of companies with immature programs were able to do so.<ref>''Leadership development: is it worth the money?'', [http://www.ccl.org Center for Creative Leadership], by Jennifer Martineau, Emily Hoole, and Tracy Patterson</ref>
== Developing individual leaders ==
Traditionally, leadership development has focused on developing the leadership abilities and attitudes of individuals.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}}
Different personal trait and characteristics can help or hinder a person's leadership effectiveness<ref>''The Leadership Development Handbook'', [http://www.ccl.org Center for Creative Leadership] and Organizational Behavior, 4th ed, by Stephen Robbins, Bruce Millet & Terry Waters-Marsh, published by Prentice Hall</ref> and require formalized programs for developing leadership competencies.
Classroom-style training and associated reading for leadership development may ail from the possible divergence between knowing what to do and doing what one knows; [[management]] expert [[Henry Mintzberg]] is one person to highlight this dilemma. It is estimated{{by whom|date=September 2014}} that as little as 15% of learning from traditional classroom-style training results in sustained [[behavior change (individual)|behavioral change]] within workplaces.<ref>See {{cite journal | author = Cromwell S., Kolb J. | year = 2004 | title = An examination of work-environment support factors affecting transfer of supervisory skills training to the work place | url = | journal = Human Resource Development Quarterly | volume = 15 | issue = 4| pages = 449–71 | doi=10.1002/hrdq.1115}}</ref>
The success of leadership development efforts has been linked{{by whom|date=September 2014}} to three variables:<ref>See Baldwin, T. & Ford, K. (1988), "Transfer Of Training: A Review And Directions For Future Research', ''Personnel Psychology'', Spring, Vol. 41 Issue 1, p63-105</ref>
# Individual learner characteristics # Quality and nature of the leadership development program # Support for behavioral change from the leader's supervisor.
Military officer-training academies, such as the [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]], go to great lengths to accept only candidates who show the highest potential to lead well.<ref>Organizational Behavior, 4th ed, by Stephen Robbins, Bruce Millet & Terry Waters-Marsh, published by Prentice Hall</ref> Personal characteristics that are associated{{by whom|date=September 2014}} with successful leadership development include leader motivation to learn, a high achievement drive and personality traits such as openness to experience, an internal focus of control, and [[self-monitoring]]. In order to develop individual leaders, supervisors or superiors must conduct an individual assessment.<ref>{{cite book|title=ADRP 6-22, Army Leadership|date=August 2012|publisher=United States Army|pages=7–9|url=http://cape.army.mil/repository/doctrine/adrp6-22.pdf}}</ref>
Development is also more likely to occur when the design of the development program:
* Integrates a range of developmental experiences over a set period of time (e.g., 6–12 months). These experiences may include [[360 degree feedback]], experiential classroom style programs, [[business school]] style coursework, [[executive coaching]], reflective journaling, [[mentoring]] and more. * Involves [[goal-setting]], following an assessment of key developmental needs and then an evaluation of the achievement of goals after a given time period.
Among key concepts in leadership development one may find:
* Experiential learning: Positioning the individual in the focus of the learning process, going through the four stages of experiential learning as formulated by [[David A. Kolb]]: *# Concrete experience. *# Observation and reflection. *# Forming abstract concepts. *# Testing in new situations. * Self efficacy: The right training and coaching should bring about 'self efficacy' in the trainee, as Albert Bandura formulated: a person's belief about his capabilities to produce effects. * Visioning: Developing the ability to formulate a clear image of the aspired future of an organization unit. * Attitude: Attitude plays a major role in being a leader.
== Developing leadership at a collective level ==
Leadership can also be developed by strengthening the connection between, and alignment of, the efforts of individual leaders and the systems through which they influence organizational operations. This has led to a differentiation between [[leader development]] and leadership development.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Leadership development can build on the development of individuals (including followers) to become leaders. In addition, it also needs to focus on the interpersonal linkages in the team.
Following the credo of people as an organization's most valuable [[Resource-based view|resource]] , some organizations address the development of these resources (including leadership).
In contrast, the concept of "[[employeeship]]" recognizes that what it takes to be a good leader is not too dissimilar to what it takes to be a good employee. Therefore, bringing the notional leader together with the team to explore these similarities (rather than focusing on the differences) brings positive results. This approach has been particularly successful in Sweden where the power distance between manager and team is small.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
== Succession planning ==
The development of "high potentials" to take over leadership when the time comes the current leadership to leave their positions is known as [[succession planning]]. This type of leadership development usually requires the extensive transfer of an individual between departments. In many [[multinational corporation|multinational]]s, it usually requires international transfer and experience to build a future leader.
Succession planning requires a sharp focus on the organization's future and [[vision statement|vision]], in order to align leadership development with the future that the organization aspires to create. Thus successive leadership development is based not only on knowledge and history but also on a dream. For such a plan to be successful, a screening of future leadership should be based not only on "what we know and have" but also on "what we aspire to become".
Persons involved in succession planning should include current leadership members who can articulate the future vision. Three critical dimensions should be considered:<!--<ref>According to Meir Jacob and Amit Cohen (1995) cannot found : https://scholar.google.de/scholar?q=Meir+Jacob+Amit+Cohen+%281995%29&btnG=&hl=de&as_sdt=0%2C5???http://www.bhc.global/leadership-consulting/</ref> -->
# Skills and knowledge; # Role perception and degree of acceptance of leading role; and, # [[Self-efficacy]].<ref>{{cite journal|authorlink=Albert Bandura|author=Albert Bandura|year=1977|title=Self-efficacy: Toward a unifying theory of behavioral change|journal=Psychological Review|volume=84|pages=191–215|doi=10.1037/0033-295x.84.2.191}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Action learning]] * [[Organization development]] * [[Executive development]] * [[Executive education]] * [[Business acumen]] * [[Collaborative leadership]] * [[Leadership Studies]] * [[Trait Leadership]] * [[YGLP]] * [[Halogen Foundation (Singapore)|Halogen Foundation]], an international programme to develop young leaders
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leadership Development}} [[Category:Human resource management]] [[Category:Leadership studies]]

revision.text:
The '''London Challenge''' was a school improvement programme launched by the UK's [[Labour Party (UK)#"New Labour" – in government, 1997–2010|Labour Government]] in 2003.<ref name=TBrighouseLondonCouncils>{{cite web|last1=Brighouse|first1=Tim|title=Local Authorities and the London Challenge|url=http://www.londoncouncils.gov.uk/our-key-themes/children-and-young-people/education-and-school-places/lessons-london/tim-brighouse|website=London Councils|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> The policy document "Transforming London Secondary Schools" set out the aims of the programme, which was designed to create a "step change" in the performance of London secondary schools.<ref name=TransformingLondonSecSchools>{{cite web|title=Transforming London Secondary Schools|url=http://www.education.gov.uk/publications/eOrderingDownload/DfES-0368-2003.pdf|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130401151715/http://www.education.gov.uk/publications/eOrderingDownload/DfES-0368-2003.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 April 2013|website=National Archives|publisher=DFES|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref>
The initiative has been credited by [[Ofsted]] and others for a significant improvement in London's state education system.<ref name=OfstedLondonChallenge>{{cite web|title=London Challenge|url=http://www.ofsted.gov.uk/resources/london-challenge|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20141124154759/http://www.ofsted.gov.uk/resources/london-challenge|dead-url=yes|archive-date=24 November 2014|publisher=Ofsted|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> More recent studies have identified the London Challenge as one factor in several that contributed to significant enhancements in pupil outcomes.<ref name=CfBTReport2014>{{cite web|title=Lessons from London Schools: investigating the success|url=https://www.cfbt.com/en-GB/Research/Research-library/2014/r-london-schools-2014|website=CfBT Education Trust|publisher=CfBT Education Trust|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref>
The London Challenge programme was initially aimed at [[secondary schools]] and was intended to run until 2008. However, it was subsequently extended until 2011, and expanded to include [[primary schools]], and two additional '''City Challenge''' areas; [[Greater Manchester]] and the [[Black Country]].<ref name=JRFLondonChallenge>{{cite web|last1=Kidson|first1=Marc|last2=Norris|first2=Emma|title=Implementing the London Challenge|url=http://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/sites/default/files/publications/Implementing%20the%20London%20Challenge%20-%20final_0.pdf|publisher=The Joseph Rowntree Foundation|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=CityChallenge>{{cite web|title=City Challenge: For World Class Education|url=http://education.gov.uk/publications/eorderingdownload/worldclasseducation.pdf|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130401151715/http://education.gov.uk/publications/eorderingdownload/worldclasseducation.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 April 2013|website=National Archives|publisher=DfES|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
== History == === London Challenge (2003 - 2011)=== In 2002 the British Government created a new set of policies focusing on London's state secondary schools,which were at that time performing poorly in comparison to the rest of the country. The policies were collectively known as the London Challenge and their objectives were:<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge" /> * to raise standards in the poorest performing schools; * to narrow the attainment gap between pupils in London; * to create more good and outstanding schools.
The London Challenge depended on close cooperation with [[Local Authorities]], and in particular five '''Key Areas''' were singled out for close attention, Tower Hamlets, Newham, Lewisham, Hackney, Westminster.<ref name="TBrighouseLondonCouncils"/><ref name="TransformingLondonSecSchools" /><ref name="JRFLondonChallenge" />
One of the distinctive features of London Challenge was a focus on partnership and shared purpose between schools, whilst avoiding stigmatising schools through the use of negative language.<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge"/> The term '''"Keys to Success"''' was used to identify those schools that would require the most intensive intervention.<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge"/> A series of "sector led" support mechanisms were put in place.<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge"/> Independent, experienced education experts, known as '''London Challenge Advisers''', were appointed to each of the Keys to Success schools to provide tailored help. The advisers were supported by an administrative team in the Department for Education (DfE).<ref name="OfstedLondonChallenge"/> They worked closely with experienced education professionals, appointed by the DfE, known as '''National Leaders of Education (NLE)''' or '''Local Leaders of Education (LLE)''', as well as local authority appointed '''School Improvement Partners (SIP)''' and other local authority officers to develop a bespoke intervention programmes.<ref name="DfEEvaluation2012"/> The cost of the support and the services brokered by the adviser came directly from the DfE.<ref name="OfstedLondonChallenge"/><ref name=InstEd>{{cite web|title=All about the Challenge|url=https://www.ioe.ac.uk/newsEvents/documents/News_and_Events_Magazines/London_InstEd_issue_4.pdf|website=Institute of Education|publisher=Institute of Education|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> In some areas school improvement services were outsourced to consultants,<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge"/> though from 2007 specialist services to the Keys to Success schools were supplied by a single education consultancy company under a '''Challenge Service Contract'''.<ref name="DfEEvaluation2012"/><ref name=ELChallengeServices>{{cite web|title=DfE School Improvement Provider in London|url=http://www.educationlondon.org.uk/dfelondon/|website=Education London|publisher=Education London|accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref>
School to school peer support was also a feature of the London Challenge programme. Some particularly successful schools were awarded '''Teaching School''' status, giving them the remit and opportunity to support other schools in their local community.<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge" /> Another initiative was the annual '''"Families of Schools"''' report which grouped all of London's state schools into numbered families with other similar schools.<ref name=FoS2011Secondary>{{cite web|title=Families of schools 2011: London secondary schools|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/families-of-schools-2011-london-secondary-schools|website=Gov.uk|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=FoS2011Primary>{{cite web|title=Families of schools 2011: London primary schools|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/families-of-schools-2011-london-primary-schools|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> This was aimed at middle and senior leaders in schools, allowing them to compare their performance with their peer schools and to share best practice on improvement initiatives, although there is no evidence that the resource was widely used for those purposes.<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge" />
The London Challenge incorporated the '''14-19 Pathfinders''' initiative which aimed to define and develop improved "learning pathways" for students in this age group.<ref name=1419PathfindersConsultation>{{cite web|title=A vision for 14-19 in London : pan-London learner offer consultation|url=http://dera.ioe.ac.uk/5258/|website=DERA|publisher=DfES|accessdate=4 July 2015}}</ref>
For schools that needed support beyond the classroom, the '''Extended School''' concept was introduced, creating hubs for services to be offered directly to students and their families.<ref name="TransformingLondonSecSchools" /> The London Challenge also introduced the [[Teach First]] initiative to encourage highly academic graduates into the teaching profession.<ref name="TransformingLondonSecSchools" />
In 2008 the Government announced an expansion of the London Challenge to include primary schools, and the programme was extended until 2011.<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge" /><ref name="CityChallenge" />
=== City Challenge (2008 - 2011)=== The 2008 extension of the London Challenge initiative also expanded it to include two new geographical areas – [[Greater Manchester]] and the [[Black Country]]. The programme was renamed for those areas as the City Challenge, but continued to be known as the London Challenge in the capital.<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge" /><ref name="CityChallenge" /> The City Challenge programme was tailored to local needs, using many of the same approaches adopted in the London Challenge.<ref name="CityChallenge" />
== Evaluation == [[Ofsted]] first reported on the impact of the London Challenge in 2006, and found that, between 2001 and 2005, London's GCSE results had improved faster in London than in England as a whole.<ref name=Ofsted2006>{{cite web|title=Secretary of State sends letter of congratulation to all London Heads following successful Ofsted report|url=http://dfes.gov.uk/londonchallenge/|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20070108123845/dfes.gov.uk/londonchallenge/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 January 2007|website=National Archives|publisher=DfES|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> A subsequent report in 2010 corroborated those findings, finding that the "London Challenge has continued to improve outcomes for pupils in London’s primary and secondary schools at a faster rate than nationally. London’s secondary schools continue to perform better than those in the rest of England".<ref name="OfstedLondonChallenge"/>
A Government commissioned report from the [[Institute for Policy Studies|Institute for Policy Studies in Education]], published in 2012, evaluated the outcomes of the City Challenge programme and, retrospectively the London Challenge Programme.<ref name=DfEEvaluation2012>{{cite web|title=Evaluation of the city challenge programme|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/evaluation-of-the-city-challenge-programme|website=Department for Education|publisher=DfE|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> It found that the majority of the initial targets were achieved, and while acknowledging the backdrop of wider educational initiatives concluded that the "most plausible explanation for the greater improvement in Challenge areas is that the City Challenge programme was responsible".
A report from the [[Joseph Rowntree Foundation]] in 2014 concluded that "during the period of the London Challenge, secondary school performance in London saw a dramatic improvement, and local authorities in inner London went from the worst performing to the best performing nationally." However they noted the difficulty of isolating the specific effect of the London Challenge against a wider background of education policy changes. The report's assessment of the City Challenge was more mixed "in part because [the City Challenge areas] had less time for these practices to properly embed." However it was found that some positive developments had been sustained beyond the end of the City Challenge programme in 2011.<ref name="JRFLondonChallenge" />
Also in 2014, the [[CfBT Education Trust]] published findings of their own investigation into the reported success of London schools during the period of the London Challenge.<ref name="CfBTReport2014" /> This concluded that this success couldn't be explained in terms of contextual advantages such as gentrification, ethnicity and opportunity. Nor could they be fully attributable to resourcing factors such as finance, teacher recruitment and school building quality, although these did help the improvements to "flourish". The success was, instead, attributed to the combined effect of four Government interventions: London Challenge, [[Teach First]], the [[Academy (English school)|academies programme]] and improved support from local authorities. It was also concluded to be dependent on "effective leadership at every level of the system".
Later the same year, research from the [[University of Bristol]] largely attributed London's improvements in pupil progress over the London Challenge period to ethnic composition rather than specific Government interventions.<ref name=BristolUni2014>{{cite web|last1=Burgess|first1=Simon|title=Understanding the success of London’s schools|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/media-library/sites/cmpo/migrated/documents/wp333.pdf|website=University of Bristol|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref> Nevertheless, the paper concluded that "for other measures of attainment, the London premium is halved but remains significant."
A subsequent report by the Centre for Analysis of Social Exclusion at the LSE demonstrated that most of the London effect could be accounted for by the improved performance in London primary schools, that there had not been any significant difference in the ethnic composition in London over the timeframe studied, and that the improved performance in primaries certainly coincided with the introduction of the National Literacy Strategies, though why they might have had more impact in London than elsewhere wasn't certain. The report is called Understanding the improved performance of disadvantaged pupils in London, and can be found online. <ref>http://sticerd.lse.ac.uk/dps/case/spcc/wp21.pdf</ref>
The UK's national media has shown a strong interest in the success of the London Challenge and its legacy.<ref name=GuardianDec2013>{{cite news|last1=Tomlinson|first1=Mike|title=How London Challenge turned capital's schools around|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2013/dec/11/london-challenge-turned-poor-schools-around|accessdate=29 June 2015|work=The Guardian|date=11 December 2013}}</ref> <ref name=TES>{{cite news|last1=Stewart|first1=William|title=The challenge now is to hang on to this success|url=https://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=6074357|accessdate=29 June 2015|work=Times Educational Supplement|date=28 March 2011}}</ref> <ref name=BBCFeb2013>{{cite news|last1=Berg|first1=Sanchia|title=How can schools nationwide mimic London's improvement?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-21534863|accessdate=29 June 2015|work=BBC News|date=21 February 2013}}</ref><ref name=Telegraph2013>{{cite news|last1=Munby|first1=Steve|title=London schools are a UK education success story|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/educationopinion/10475000/London-schools-are-a-UK-education-success-story.html|accessdate=29 June 2015|work=The Telegraph|date=27 Nov 2013}}</ref><ref name=Scotland2015>{{cite news|title=Plan to tackle schools gap inspired by London Challenge|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-31289154|accessdate=5 July 2015|work=BBC News Website|date=9 Feb 2015}}</ref><ref name=CoastalSchools2014>{{cite news|last1=Weale|first1=Sally|title=Out in the cold: the coastal schools neglected by national initiatives|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2014/oct/15/coastal-schools-neglected-by-national-initiatives|accessdate=5 July 2015|work=The Guardian|date=15 Oct 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}} <!--- After listing your sources please cite them using inline citations and place them after the information they cite. Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --->

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=May 2008}}
The '''National Science Education Standards''' ('''NSES''')<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.csun.edu/science/ref/curriculum/reforms/nses/|title=National Science Education Standards|website=www.csun.edu|access-date=2018-05-23}}</ref> represent guidelines for the science education in primary and secondary schools in the [[United States]], as established by the [[United States National Research Council|National Research Council]] in 1996. These provide a set of goals for teachers to set for their students and for administrators to provide professional development. The NSES influence various states' own science learning standards (such as the [[Massachusetts Frameworks]])<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mass.gov/service-details/the-massachusetts-curriculum-frameworks-for-prek-12|title=The Massachusetts Curriculum Frameworks for PreK-12|website=Mass.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-05-23}}</ref>, and statewide [[standardized test]]ing<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wvea.org/content/state-school-board-approves-reducing-standardized-testing|title=State school board approves reducing standardized testing {{!}} WVEA|website=www.wvea.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-23}}</ref>.
==Education Reform==
The science standards is only one of a number of reforms organized around the principles of [[outcomes-based education]]. The mathematics counterpart are the controversial [[NCTM]] standards, which also de-emphasize knowledge of disconnected facts and content in favor of context-dependent critical thinking skills and process. Progressive education seeks to reform [[traditional education]], taking into account current understandings of human learning.
==Vision==
The content of these standards is based heavily on a specific model of learning, [[constructivism (learning theory)]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.teach-nology.com/currenttrends/constructivism/|title=Constructivism Learning Theory|website=www.teach-nology.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-23}}</ref>. Like [[reform mathematics]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bono|first=Melissa|date=2002-11-30|title=Reform in Mathematics Education: Rethinking the Curriculum|url=https://concept.journals.villanova.edu/article/view/313|journal=CONCEPT|language=en|volume=26|issue=0}}</ref>, which is distinguished by an emphasis on building on what a child already knows and understands, the standards intend to update the methods of science education to achieve greater effectiveness with children. The goals of the standards include:
* An outline of '''what students need to know, understand, and be able to do''' * Targets for [[scientific literacy]] at different grade levels * '''All students''' demonstrate '''high levels of performance''' * Teachers are empowered to make the decisions essential for effective learning * '''Communities of teachers and students''' are focused on learning science * Educational programs and systems '''nurture achievement'''
The intended purpose of the standards is to define teaching methods which apply to all students, regardless of age, gender, cultural or ethnic background, disabilities, aspirations, or interest and motivation in science, recognizing that different students will achieve understanding in different ways, and some students will achieve different degrees of depth and breadth of understanding depending on interest, ability, and context. However, the standards expect that all students can develop the knowledge and skills described in the standards.
The goal of scientific literacy includes inquiry, history and nature of science, personal and social perspectives of science, science, and technology, in addition to the science domains of life science, physical science, and earth and space science. Programs defined according to these standards should be [[Developmentally Appropriate Practice|developmentally appropriate]], interesting, and '''relevant''' to students’ lives.<ref>[http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=10618&page=39] The Influence of the National Science Education Standards on the Science Curriculum James D. Ellis University of Kansas</ref>
==Organization of the Standards== The NSES are organized into six categories:
* Standards for science teaching, * Standards for professional development for teachers of science * Standards for assessment in science education * Standards for science content * Standards for science education programs * Standards for science education systems
==Critics==
Many critics of [[standards-based education reform]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~hakuta/www/archives/syllabi/CalTex_SBR/whatissbr.html|title=What Is Standards-Based Reform?|last=Lab|first=Step|website=web.stanford.edu|access-date=2018-05-23}}</ref> and [[reform mathematics]] are also critical of the emphasis of the standards on process and [[inquiry-based science]] rather than learning of facts. Science assessments such as [[Washington Assessment of Student Learning|WASL]] in Washington state<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/education/different-name-but-new-state-test-similar-to-wasl/|title=Different name, but new state test similar to WASL|date=2009-08-14|work=The Seattle Times|access-date=2018-05-23|language=en-US}}</ref> contain very little factual content, and most assessment is based on the ability of students as young as the fifth grade to construct and interpret science experiments. By contrast, previous generations of high school and even college students were only expected to participate in, rather than design science experiments from scratch, complete with a list of materials. The principles of the standards are similar to controversial approaches taken to mathematics and language arts which de-emphasize basic skills traditionally taught in elementary school as being inappropriate to the ability level of some students. Yet content and skills that were traditionally taught at the college level, requiring "higher order" and "critical thinking" are brought down to K-12 to "raise standards".
==Notes==
The Five Biggest Ideas in Science, Wynn & Wiggins, 1997 and cited in Understanding by Design, Wiggins and McTighe, 2005. 9.67.
==See also== * [[Constructionist learning]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.nap.edu/html/nses/ National Science Education Standards in HTML] * [http://www.nap.edu/catalog/4962.html NSES book homepage, with link to free PDF of NSES] * [http://www.nsta.org/standards National Science Teachers Association] page on the National Science Education Standards
[[Category:Science education in the United States]] [[Category:Education in the United States]] [[Category:Standards-based education]] [[Category:Education reform]] [[Category:1996 introductions]]

revision.text:
{{advert|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox website | name = OpenClassrooms | logo = | screenshot = | url = https://openclassrooms.com/ | commercial = Yes | type = Online education | language = English, French, Spanish | num_users = 2.5 million | owner = OpenClassrooms | author = Mathieu Nebra | launch_date = 10 November 1999 | alexa = [http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/openclassrooms.com 135] (France, July 2017) }}'''OpenClassrooms''' is an online education platform for [[Vocational education|vocational training]], providing courses in [[Information technology|IT]], technology, [[entrepreneurship]], and digital skills.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/55aa02f0-fa49-11e5-8f41-df5bda8beb40.html#axzz45VK9a3Ac|title=Moocs platform OpenClassrooms aims to fill UK tech skills gap|last=Boyde|first=Emma|date=2016-04-10|newspaper=Financial Times|issn=0307-1766|access-date=2016-04-20}}</ref>
Courses are conducted fully online, through a mix of video resources, online reading, real-life projects and individual mentoring sessions.
Founded in 2013 by Pierre Dubuc and Mathieu Nebra, OpenClassrooms now has 2.5 million users worldwide<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://openclassrooms.com/|title=Fully-online degree programs and free courses|website=openclassrooms.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref> and offers courses in English, French and Spanish. The company's mission is to ‘''make education accessible''’<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://openclassrooms.com/courses/how-do-we-work-at-openclassrooms/our-mission|title=Our Mission @OpenClassrooms|website=OpenClassrooms|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref>
Students can choose to follow online courses in subjects ranging from [[JavaScript|Javascript]] to Product Management, or pursue internationally recognized degree programs.
== Courses and learning paths == OpenClassrooms offers 1000+ courses<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://openclassrooms.com/courses|title=Our courses|website=openclassrooms.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cursus.edu/institutions-formations-ressources/formation/16827/site-zero-devenu-openclassrooms-des-centaines/#.WVpDqNPyjBI|title=Le site du zéro (devenu OpenClassrooms) : des centaines de cours en informatique|website=Thot Cursus|language=fr-FR|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref> focusing on in-demand skills and ranging from [[entrepreneurship]], [[digital marketing]] to [[web development]].
Since 2015, OpenClassrooms also offers what it calls learning paths.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://openclassrooms.com/paths|title=Paths|website=openclassrooms.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref> A learning path relies on real-life projects and [[mentorship]]. Additionally, students have access to courses within modules in order to get all the resources that they need.
At the end of each module, the student is asked to complete a project that is then assessed by a [[Mentorship|mentor]].
When the student has completed all their projects, their work is assessed by a jury. If the session is successful, the student is then awarded an internationally recognized diploma.
OpenClassrooms currently has 12 available degree programs in French and 7 in English (Front-end web development, Ruby development, Android development, iOS development, full-stack web development, UX design, product management). Program take from 6 to 12 months to complete and the level of the program ranges from bachelor's-level to master's-level.
== Membership structure == OpenClassrooms operates on a [[freemium]] basis.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://openclassrooms.com/premium|title=Our Premium offers|website=openclassrooms.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref>
A user can register on OpenClassrooms for free and follow all courses on the platform. The number of videos a user can watch is, however, limited to 5 per week.
A user can sign up for a Premium Solo membership (costing €20 per month) and have access to unlimited videos as well as earn certificates.
A user can sign up for a Premium Plus membership (costing from €300 per month) and follow a structured learning path consisting of projects, dedicated mentoring sessions and a state-endorsed degree at the end.
== Accreditation == OpenClassrooms is an official private distance learning establishment registered with the Board of Education in Paris, France that grants its own degrees as well as those of other academic partners.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/55aa02f0-fa49-11e5-8f41-df5bda8beb40?mhq5j=e1|title=Moocs platform OpenClassrooms aims to fill UK tech skills gap|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Upon completion of their studies and validation of their skills by an academic jury, the student will earn a bachelor's-level or master's-level diploma in the corresponding field of study.
For instance, the ''front-end web development program'' is at level 6 on the EQF (European Qualifications Framework). Thanks to the [[Bologna Process]], signed by 50 countries, the diploma is recognized by all participating countries, notably in [[Europe]].
Each path is the subject of a registration application with the National Directory of Professional Certifications ([http://www.rncp.cncp.gouv.fr/ RNCP]), via the National Commission of Professional Certifications ([http://www.cncp.gouv.fr/ CNCP]), in order for the level of the diploma to be recognized by the State.
== History == The origins of OpenClassrooms go back to 1999, when Mathieu Nebra,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://innovatorsunder35.com/innovator/mathieu-nebra|title=Mathieu Nebra {{!}} Innovators Under 35|website=innovatorsunder35.com|access-date=2016-03-24}}</ref> helped by Pierre Dubuc, launched a community site for tutorials called ''Le site du Zéro''. Its aim was to help young people to learn [[Programming language|programming languages.]]
In 2007, the site became a company, which offers online courses, [[Massive open online course|MOOC]]<nowiki/>s, and learning paths on a [[freemium]] basis. These courses are created either in house, or in partnership with universities, such as [[École Polytechnique|École polytechnique,]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rudebaguette.com/2015/03/10/moocs-go-mainstream/|title=MOOCs go mainstream in France as OpenClassrooms partners with Polytechnique|last=12|first=Joran Le Cren March|last2=Reply|first2=2015|website=Rude Baguette|access-date=2016-03-24}}</ref> and companies, such as [[IBM]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tech.london/courses/ibm-and-openclassrooms-present-build-your-web-projects-with-rest-apis|title=IBM & OpenClassrooms Present: Build your web projects with REST APIs|website=Tech.London|access-date=2016-03-24}}</ref>
In October 2015, OpenClassrooms signed a deal with the French Government which gives free Premium Solo memberships (€20 per month) to all unemployed people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/10/23/openclassrooms-premium-is-now-free-for-unemployed-people-in-france/|title=OpenClassrooms Premium Is Now Free For Unemployed People In France {{!}} TechCrunch|last=Dillet|first=Romain|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref>
In November 2016, OpenClassrooms launched its first bachelor's degree in English in Web Development, recognized internationally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thepienews.com/news/openclassrooms-launches-first-english-taught-degree/|title=OpenClassrooms launches first English-taught degree|last=News|first=The PIE|website=thepienews.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref>
In December 2016, OpenClassrooms signed a deal with Morocco's [[:fr:Agence nationale de promotion de l'emploi et des compétences|ANAPEC]] (Agence nationale de promotion de l'emploi et des compétences) and offered free Premium Solo memberships to job seekers<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tv.anapec.org/OpenClassRooms/|title=Convention de partenariat entre l'ANAPEC et OpenClassrooms|website=tv.anapec.org|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref>
By 2017, the number of OpenClassrooms user accounts reached 2 million,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://openclassrooms.com/|title=Fully-online degree programs and free courses|website=openclassrooms.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref> with the number of unique visitors reaching 3.5 million per month.
In March 2017, OpenClassrooms signed a deal with Tunisia's [[:fr:Agence nationale pour l'emploi et le travail indépendant|ANETI]] (Agence nationale pour l’emploi et le travail indépendant) and offered free Premium Solo memberships to job seekers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emploi.nat.tn/fo/Fr/global.php?page=3&id=2612|title=Focus|last=ANETI|website=www.emploi.nat.tn|language=fr|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref>
In April 2017, OpenClassrooms launched Job Guarantee in France<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bfmbusiness.bfmtv.com/entreprise/cette-ecole-vous-rembourse-votre-formation-si-vous-ne-trouvez-pas-d-emploi-1135352.html|title=Cette école vous rembourse votre formation si vous ne trouvez pas d'emploi|last=BUSINESS|first=BFM|website=BFM BUSINESS|language=fr-FR|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref> which states that if students do not find employment within six months after graduating from OpenClassrooms, their tuition fees will be refunded. The company launched this internationally in July 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thepienews.com/news/openclassrooms-job-guarantee-online-degree-courses/|title=OpenClassrooms expands degrees, guarantees jobs|last=News|first=The PIE|website=thepienews.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-07}}</ref>
In June 2017, OpenClassrooms launched a partnership program with [[Capgemini]], one of the world's largest [[IT consulting]], [[outsourcing]] and [[professional services]] companies. This new program is called ‘online apprenticeship’ and aims to build fully online, company-tailored curricula, source candidates, provide on-the-job training, and award them with a bachelor's or master's degree<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/key-creating-global-talent-supply-chain-pierre-dubuc?trk=v-feed&lipi=urn:li:page:d_flagship3_university;y+9Mm1TFZbd4XOG4h2cyqA==|title=The Key To Creating A Global Talent Supply Chain|date=2017-06-22|access-date=2017-07-07|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://start.lesechos.fr/continuer-etudes/master-ms-mba/le-premier-contrat-d-alternance-100-en-ligne-lance-a-la-rentree-8714.php|title=Le premier contrat d’alternance 100% en ligne lancé à la rentrée|work=start.lesechos.fr|access-date=2017-07-07|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
== Talks and awards == In 2015, Mathieu Nebra was named among MIT Innovators Under 35<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://innovatorsunder35.com/innovator/mathieu-nebra|title=Mathieu Nebra {{!}} Innovators Under 35|website=innovatorsunder35.com|access-date=2016-03-24}}</ref> by [[MIT Technology Review]]. In 2016, Pierre Dubuc became one of the Forbes 30 Under 30,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/30-under-30-europe-2016/social-entrepreneurs/#5b4e61fb61ec|title=30 Under 30 2016 Europe: Social Entrepreneurs|website=Forbes|access-date=2016-03-24}}</ref> in the category "social entrepreneurship".
In May 2016, OpenClassrooms won the ACSEL’R award for digital transformation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.acsel.asso.fr/et-les-laureats-des-acselr-awards-2016-sont/|title=Et les Lauréats des ACSEL'R Awards 2016 sont... - Acsel|date=2016-05-04|work=Acsel|access-date=2017-07-06|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
In November 2016, co-founder Pierre Dubuc presented his vision of the education of the future at the Young Leaders session during the World Policy Conference 2016.<ref>{{Citation|last=OpenClassrooms|title=Pierre Dubuc's speech at the World Policy Conference 2016|date=2017-02-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VxGzp7fQg4A|accessdate=2017-07-06}}</ref>
In July 2017, OpenClassrooms was one of the finalists at the EdTechXGlobal Europe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ecosystem.edtechxeurope.com/2017-edtech-all-stars-awards|title=2017 EdTechXGlobal All Stars Startup Awards|last=EdTechXGlobal|website=ecosystem.edtechxeurope.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-06}}</ref>
== External links == * {{Official website|https://openclassrooms.com/}} * [http://blog.openclassrooms.com/en/ Blog]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Trimming long description of study characteristics (not typically done on Wikipedia/in encyclopedias). Also, this is not how we cite papers on Wikipedia.
revision.text:
'''Peer-mediated instruction''' ('''PMI''') is an approach in [[special education]] where [[peer group|peers]] of the target students are trained to provide necessary tutoring in educational, behavioral, and/or social concerns.(Chan et al., 2009). In PMI, peers may mediate by [[Modelling (psychology)|modeling]] appropriate behavior themselves, using [[Response Prompting Procedures|prompting procedures]] to elicit appropriate behavior from the target students, and [[Reinforcement|reinforcing]] appropriate behavior when it occurs. The peer tutors are chosen from the target students' classrooms, trained to mediate and closely observed during mediation. Among the advantages noted to the technique, it takes advantage of the positive potential of [[Peer pressure#Benign peer pressure|peer pressure]] and may integrate target students more fully in their peer group. Conversely, it is time consuming to implement and presents challenges in making sure that the peers follow proper techniques. However, studies have suggested it may be an effective technique for a wide range of students, including those with [[autism spectrum]] disorders.
==Procedure== A student or students will be chosen from the target student's classroom to serve as a peer tutor. Garrison-Harrell et al. (as cited in Chan et al., 2009) suggested a systematic way to choosing the peers to be involved in the treatment based on social status and teacher judgment. Students were asked to list three peers they would like to play with on the playground, three peers they would invite to a party, and three peers they consider to be good friends. Teachers reviewed the top candidates, and selected the tutors based on social skills, language skills, school attendance and classroom behavior.
The student or students chosen as peers must be properly coached before the peer relationship begins, both to understand the importance of the intervention and the methods which should be used. Instructors may model behaviors to the peer tutors and may role play with the peer tutors, allowing the peer tutors to experience both parts in the PMI relationship. Other methods for training could include visual aids, reinforcement for correct implementation, instruction manuals and video instructions. Once the PMI relationship begins, the teacher provides on-going feedback, watching the peer at all times while the intervention is being used. (Chan et al., 2009).
==Strengths and limitations== There are advantages of using PMI as an intervention strategy. First, there is never a shortage of peers to use, especially when implementing an intervention in a school or classroom. Second, students are influenced through [[observational learning]] by what they see their peers doing. Third, students are often less intimidated by a peer than they are a teacher, which makes instruction and feedback from peers potentially more effective. Fourth, it may not only offer short-term intervention benefits, but can also strengthen the target student's social ties within the classroom. Finally, research has been done with many different types of learners, including students with [[learning disability|learning disabilities]], behavior disorders and [[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]], which show that PMI may be effective for a wide range of students (Fuchs & Fuchs, 2005; Flood, Wilder, Flood & Masuda, 2002).
In 2009, ''Research in Autism Spectrum Disorders'' published a paper by Chan ''et al.'' that concluded that PMI is a potentially effective intervention approach for students with Autism disorders.
==Application to General Education classroom settings== Varying forms of peer-mediated instruction and interventions have been conducted in a great range of settings over the decades. Research has been conducted in educational and non-educational environments with positive outcomes in each. It is important to note that PMII strategies are not restricted or inclusive to education or special education, but have been found to be effective in each-as well as inclusive classroom settings. The following characteristics have been identified by Kulik & Kulik (1992), as central for successful implementation of peer-mediated instruction.
*''Expectations for student learning''. Teachers should establish high expectation levels. No students are expected to fall below the level of learning needed to be successful at the next level of education. *''Careful orientation to lessons''. Teachers must clearly describe the relationship of a current lesson to previous study. Students are reminded of key concepts or skills previously covered. *''Clear and focused instructions to participants''. *''Close teacher monitoring of student progress''. Frequently formal and informal monitoring of student learning by teachers. Teachers must require that students are accountable for their product and learning. *''Re-teach''. If students show signs of confusion, misinterpretation or misunderstanding, the teacher must be responsible to teach again. *''Use classtime for learning''. Students must pace themselves and should be monitored for task completion. *''Positive and personal teacher and student interaction''. Cooperative Learning and Peer Tutoring Strategies are instruction methods of choice in many classrooms as they are noted for preventing and alleviating many social problems related to children, adolescents, and young adults.
==See also== *[[Classwide Peer Tutoring]] *[[Peer education]] *[[Peer feedback]] *[[Peer mentoring]] *[[Peer tutor]] *[[Peer-led team learning]] *[[Peer support]]
==References== #Chan, J.M., Lang, R., Rispoli, M., O’Reilly, M., Sigafoos, J., Cole, H. (2009). "Use of peer-mediated interventions in the treatment of autism spectrum disorders: A systematic review." ''Research in Autism Spectrum Disorders'', 3, 876-889. #Flood, W.A., Wilder, D.A., Flood, A.L., Masuda, A. (2002). "Peer-mediated reinforcement plus prompting as treatment for off-task behavior in children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder." ''Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis'', 35(2), 199-204. #Fuchs, D. & Fuchs, L. (2005). "Peer-assisted learning strategies: Promoting word recognition, fluency, and reading comprehension in young children." ''Journal of Special Education'', 39, 34-44. #Hall, T., & Stegila, A. (2003). Peer mediated instruction and intervention. Wakefield, MA: National Center on Accessing the General Curriculum.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Peer-Mediated Instruction}} [[Category:Educational practices]] [[Category:Peer learning]] [[Category:Special education]]

revision.comment: dab Private Pilot License
revision.text:
'''Qualifying Cross Country''', also abbreviated '''QXC''', is a flight training standard. Depending on the license type and country's regulatory requirements, it is generally a flight carried out solo, near the end of student training towards a Private Pilots License ([[Private Pilot License|PPL]]) or [[Private Ultralight Pilot]] license. Normally the student would be expected to plan a triangular course [[navigation]] with one leg more than a specified distance and with one or more landings away from the home airfield.
The QXC is considered by many pilots to be the single most challenging part of gaining the first pilots license.
[[Category:Flight training]]
{{aviation-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} The '''RUM General Library''' ({{lang-es|Biblioteca del Recinto Universitario de Mayagüez}}) is the main library for the [[University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez]]. It consists of a main library and a specialized collection.<ref>{{Cite web | language = Spanish | title = Sobre Nosotros / Misión y Visión | url=http://www.uprm.edu/library/biblioteca.html | accessdate = 9 August 2010}}</ref>
==Building== The Mayagüez Campus General library building was inaugurated in 1963.<ref name=UPRM>{{Cite web | language = Spanish | title = Biblioteca | url=http://www.uprm.edu/oiip/building.php?id=42&lang=2 | accessdate = 9 August 2010}}</ref> It was designed by [[Henry Klumb]].<ref name=UPRM/> The main library has an area of approximately {{convert|109064|sqft|m2}} and has three floors.<ref name=UPRM/>
==Services== The Mayagüez Campus General Library serves the local campus community as well as residents of [[Mayagüez]] and nearby towns. It fully supports UPRM education and research mission and objectives by providing adequate library and information resources, facilities and services.
The library is divided in three principal areas: Technical Services, Services to the Public and Technological Services.<ref name=propuesta>{{Cite web | language = Spanish | title = PROPUESTA PARA EL ESTABLECIMIENTO DEL PROGRAMA DE BACHILLERATO EN MANEJO DE RECURSOS NATURALES EN EL DEPARTAMENTO DE AGRONOMÍA Y SUELOS DE LA FACULTAD DE CIENCIAS AGRÍCOLAS EN EL RECINTO DE MAYAGÜEZ DE LA UNIVERSIDAD DE PUERTO RICO | url=http://agricultura.uprm.edu/documentos/recursosnaturales.pdf | pages = 30| accessdate = 9 August 2010}}</ref>
UPRM library holdings include 215,830 [[Volume (bibliography)|volumes]]; 5,259 [[Academic journal|journals]]; 263,982 microfiches; 12,719 microcards; 19,486 [[microfilms]]; 561,641 government documents; 949 [[films]]; 8,149 [[map]]s; 8,458 [[sound recordings]]; 606 musical scores; 375 sound magnetic tapes; 4,550 [[videocassettes]]; 5,109 [[CD]]/[[DVD]]s; 3,648 [[theses]]; 7.5 million United States patents, and 4 million United States-issued trademarks.
The library is a selective depository for publications of the U.S. government and one of the coordinating agencies of the Puerto Rico Census Data Center under the Planning Board of Puerto Rico. It serves as depository for the U.S. Census Bureau publications. The library has been a member of the Patent and Trademark Depository Library Program of the [[U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]] since March 1995. (It the only library outside the continental United States that is a member of that organization.)<ref name=propuesta/>
It has a seating capacity of 774, eight individual study rooms for graduate students and faculty, eight study rooms for group discussions and collaborative work, a computer lab with 57 computers, and two library instruction classrooms. Also, it has a conference room and two smaller meeting rooms.<ref>http://www.uprm.edu/catalog/UndergradCatalog2009-2010.pdf pag 47</ref>
==References== {{Portal|Puerto Rico|Library and information science}} {{Reflist}}
{{University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez}} {{coord|18|12|39.66|N|67|08|29.64|W|region:US-PR|display=title}}
[[Category:Library buildings completed in 1963]] [[Category:Academic libraries]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Mayagüez, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Libraries in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez]]

page.title: School Teachers' Pay and Conditions Document

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/194.61.223.53|194.61.223.53]] ([[User talk:194.61.223.53|talk]]) to last version by 2A00:23C4:D204:A900:8DD5:2272:6D9C:D76
revision.text:
The '''School Teachers' Pay and Conditions Document''' (STPCD) is an annually-published document which forms a part of the contract of all [[teacher]]s and [[head teacher]]s in [[maintained school]]s in [[England]] and [[Wales]]. The document is binding on all maintained schools and [[local education authority|local education authorities]].
==Content== The current version of the STPCD is formed of four sections, although the document itself is actually included in section 2. The document is accompanied by an explanatory introduction and statutory guidance.
===Section One=== The introduction of the document sets out its legal status, and gives summary details of key changes to the document in its most recent version.
===Section Two=== Section two is the main legal document, which sets out the key pay and conditions arrangements for teachers. Although sections vary, recent documents have been formed of 12 parts, outlines of which are listed:
====Part One==== This sets out the commencement arrangements for the document, and gives a detailed glossary of definitions for terms used within the document.
====Part Two==== This sets out the context of the document, including the need for teachers' pay to be reviewed annually, and setting requirements on schools to have a pay policy.
====Parts Three to Seven==== These parts set out the arrangements for the pay of head teachers, deputy head teachers, assistant head teacher, qualified teachers and unqualified teachers, including arrangements for [[performance related pay]], [[teaching and learning responsibility]] awards and other supplementary pay awards
====Parts Eight to Twelve==== These parts relate to the conditions under which teachers and school leaders are employed, including setting out the number of days to be worked, and the number of hours which teachers may be directed to work. Notably, it also includes a clause which requires a teacher to "work such reasonable additional hours as may be needed to enable him to discharm m ge effectively his professional duties"
These parts also detail the arrangements for planning, preparation and assessment time - that is, the allocation of time which must be set aside for teachers' planning and assessment during the school day, and during which time they cannot be required to teach pupils.
===Section Three=== This section gives general guidance for employers and employees on the application of the document.
===Section Four=== This section gives guidance on recent changes to teachers' pay and conditions since the introduction of the National Workload Agreement between the [[government]] and [[trade union|union]]s. This agreement saw the removal of administrative work from teachers' responsibilities, and introduced compulsory non-contact time for all teachers.
==New documents== The content of each new document is formed following proposals from the [[School Teachers' Review Body]]. The body makes recommendations to the secretary of state, having received evidence from various bodies, including the secretary of state, teaching unions, and the [[Department for Children, Schools and Families]].
==Enactment== Each year, the document is constructed by the [[Department for Children, Schools and Families]] outlining the pay and conditions of teachers in schools. It must then be enacted by secondary legislation, and this too is produced annually in the name of [[Secretary of State for Education and Skills]]. The [[Statutory Instrument]] is currently issued under the provisions of the [[Education Act 2002]].
The secondary legislation usually takes the form of a statutory instrument entitled "The Education (School Teachers' Pay and Conditions) Order". This document revokes the previous year's document, replacing it with the new version. The legislation is normally brought in during August of each year, coming into effect on 1 September before new school terms start.
==External links== * [http://www.teachernet.gov.uk/management/payandperformance/pay/ Teachernet Pay information] - includes full text of the document.
[[Category:Education in England]] [[Category:School terminology]]

10000 [[Zagreb]]
[[Croatia]] |coordinates = |schooltype = |religious_affiliation = |established = {{Start date and age|1959|df=y}} |founded = |opened = |founder = |status = |sister_school = |administrator = |rector = |headmaster = Ivo Klarić |grades = |enrolment = |students = |pupils = |classes = |classes offered = |language = [[Croatian language|Croatian]] |hours_in_day = |classrooms = |campus = [[Urban structure|Urban]] |colours = |colors = |song = |publication = |newspaper = |graduates = |website = [http://ss-elektrotehnicka-zg.skole.hr/ ss-elektrotehnicka-zg.skole.hr] |footnotes = }} '''School of Electrotechnics Zagreb''' ({{lang-hr|Elektrotehnička škola Zagreb}}) is a school specialised for electro-technicians, computer technicians and technicians for electro-engineering. It was founded in 1959 as ''Center for educating "[[Rade Končar]]"''. In 1991 the school changed its name to School of Electrotechnics which is still its name. Director of school is [[Ivo Klarić]] and his assistant is [[Stjepan Novoselac]]. ==External links== *[http://ss-elektrotehnicka-zg.skole.hr Electrotehnic school site] {{coord missing|Croatia}} {{High schools in Zagreb}} [[Category:Schools in Croatia]] [[Category:Education in Zagreb]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1959]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Zagreb]] {{croatia-school-stub}} {{Zagreb-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
A '''slam book''' is a [[notebook]] (commonly the spiral-bound type) which is passed among children and teenagers. The keeper of the book starts by posing a question (which may be on any subject) and the book is then passed round for each contributor to fill in their own answer to the question.<ref>{{cite book | last = Mansour | first = David | title = From Abba to Zoom: A Pop Culture Encyclopedia of the Late 20th Century | publisher = Andrews McMeel Publishing | year = 2005 | url = | isbn = 0-7407-5118-2 | page = 436}}</ref>
Slam books were also a source of bullying between students—where students "lived in fear" of the "biting comments" written anonymously under their names, "on the order of what today might be a Tweet or a Facebook comment". <ref>''[[The Washington Post]]'': [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/10/AR2010121005373.html]</ref> A slam book containing cruel comments was featured in episode 3.20 ("Kids Can Be Cruel") of the 1980s TV show "Facts of Life".<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0575370/plotsummary?ref_=tt_ov_pl IMDB episode summary].</ref>
One early reference to slam books can be found in the November 18, 1928 issue of The Central New Jersey Home News where it was reported as a new fad among New Brunswick high school students.<ref> Republished in The Central New Jersey Home News (New Brunswick, New Jersey) on 22 Nov 1953.</ref> It was defined in ''The Vocabulary of Jazzdom" in 1922 as "a diary in which you "knock" your friends." .<ref>The Tiller and Toiler (Larned, Kansas) on 25 May 1922.</ref>
One newspaper article from 1930 argued that slam books could be a great thing for humanity. ''"Psychology, industry and the ghastly exposure to the late war have changed [the Victorian era's faux veneer of sentimentality and taboos]. We have learned the price of sentimentality. The youngster's of today are facing life and themselves as is."''<ref> ''Listen World'' by Elsie Robinson, Wausau Daily Herald (Wausau, Wisconsin) on 01 Jul 1930.</ref>
In general, however, slam books were seen in a negative light. A slam book was briefly the focus in the murder investigation of Carole Lee Kensinger in 1948. <ref>''Slam Book Latest Clue In Girl Slaying'' as reported in The Pittsburgh Press (Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania) on 17 Dec 1948. See also The Daily Republican (Monongahela, Pennsylvania) on 17 Dec 1948.</ref>
Slam books crossed racial barriers and were popular among African American high school communities in the 1950s. <ref> ''Notebook Version of "Facebook" Was Popular'' by Theresa Greenwood, in The Star Press (Muncie, Indiana), dated Feb 5, 2011.</ref> And the books were not limited to the US. In 2005, friends created a slam book as a going away present for 16 year old Richa Thapa who emigrated from Nepal to the US.<ref> ''International student finds America not that different from native Nepal'' by Heather Wilson in The Hays Daily News (Hays, Kansas) dated 18 Oct 2005.</ref> In 1999, Claire Morris-Dobbie launched "SLAM: A New Way To Tell The truth", a pre-made "slam book" with online tie in features in an attempt to combine nostalgia with the growing World Wide Web. It was billed as a "kinder and gentler" slam book for teens and pre-teens with the goal of encouraging them to think and communicate, write and express themselves. <ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19990208020354/http://www.slammit.com/ SLAM - A new way to tell the truth]; see also ''Dare To Bare It In'' by Michelle Ramos, published in the Honolulu Star-Bulletin (Honolulu, Hawaii) on Jan 8, 1999.</ref>
Slam books can also exist in virtual formats. Web-based slam book sites have attracted controversy for hosting virtual slam books in which individuals or organizations are targeted for criticism that constitutes bullying or defamation.<ref>''[[Tampa Tribune]]'': [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/tampatribune/access/118663294.html?dids=118663294:118663294&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+08%2C+2002&author=CANDACE+J.+SAMOLINSKI+and+RONNIE+BLAIR&pub=Tampa+Tribune&desc=Issues+Raised+Over+Web+Slambooks&pqatl=google Issues Raised Over Web Slambooks]</ref>
Some point to slam books as the analog precursor to anonymous trolling and negative social interactions on Twitter and Facebook. "''Passing handwritten notes or "slam books" has since been replaced with online tools such as IM, websites, blogs, cell phones etc.''"<ref>''Don't blame technology for the cruelty of its users'' by Rick Malwizt published in The Courier-News (Bridgewater, New Jersey) on 06 Oct 2010.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == Some of the virtual slambook websites are listed below: * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160307071935/http://www.slambook.org/ Slambook.org] – Online version of slam book operated from India
[[Category:School terminology]] [[Category:Collaborative writing]]
{{US-edu-stub}}

revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:U.S. Marine Corps Sea Knight SPIE rig over St. Louis, Missouri.ogv]] → [[File:U.S. Marine Corps CH-46 Sea Knight SPIE rig over St. Louis, Missouri.ogv]] uploader requested.
revision.text:
{{Multiple image |image1=U.S. Marine Corps CH-46 Sea Knight SPIE rig over St. Louis, Missouri.ogv |caption1=Early 2010s video of U.S. Marines flying over St. Louis, Missouri on a SPIE rig attached to a USMC [[Boeing Vertol CH-46 Sea Knight|CH-46 Sea Knight]] |image2=CVN-69-SPIE-training.jpg |caption2=Special Purpose Insertion/Extraction training between a [[Sikorsky SH-60 Seahawk]] helicopter and {{USS|Dwight D. Eisenhower}}}} {{Multiple image |image3=Aerocordage-calvi.jpg |caption3=[[2nd Foreign Parachute Regiment|2eme REP]] Legionnaires extract from a [[Aérospatiale SA 330 Puma|Puma]] over Calvi. |image4=Special Purpose Insertion Extraction SPIE.jpg |caption4=Personnel suspended from a Seahawk helicopter for a SPIE operation}} The '''Special Patrol Insertion/Extraction''' (SPIE) system was developed as a means to rapidly insert and/or extract a [[reconnaissance]] [[patrol]] from an area that does not permit a helicopter to land. SPIE has application for rough terrain as well as water inserts/extracts. It is an adaptation of the [[Vietnam War]]-era [[STABO]] rig.<ref>http://www.vietnamgear.com/kit.aspx?kit=661</ref>
Generally, the SPIE rope is lowered into the pickup area from a hovering helicopter. Patrol personnel, each wearing a harness with an attached [[carabiner]], hook up to a D-ring inserted in the SPIE rope. A second safety line is attached to a second D-ring located above the first. The helicopter lifts vertically from an extract zone until the rope and personnel are clear of obstructions, then proceeds in forward flight to a secure insert zone. The rope and personnel are treated as an external load and airspeeds, altitudes, and oscillations must be monitored.<ref>FMFM 7-40 Helicopter Rope Suspension Training (HRST) Operations</ref>
The [[United States Coast Guard]] uses a similar technique to board ships when speed and stealth are required.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
==History== The Special Personnel Insertion/Extraction was first designed by the Marines of [[1st Force Reconnaissance Company]], the Marine division's [[1st Reconnaissance Battalion]], and the [[1st Marine Aircraft Wing]] riggers. They created and combat tested several versions of the SPIE before it was officially recommended to be tested. In May 1970, the commanding general of [[3rd Marine Expeditionary Force|3rd Marine Amphibious Force]] coordinated input from the [[1st Marine Division (United States)|1st Marine Division]] and his [[1st Marine Air Wing]]. A request was sent to the [[Commandant of the Marine Corps]] and to the Development Center for certification of the SPIE rig and to its safety and use.<ref name="Meyers, 1stFORECON">Bruce F. Meyers, ''Fortune Favors the Brave: The Story of First Force Recon,'' (Annapolis, MD: Naval Institute Press, 2000).</ref>
The parachute test jumpers of the Naval Parachute Unit (NPU) and Marine Corps, all qualified parachutist designers and engineers, assembled together at [[Naval Air Facility El Centro|El Centro]] for the initial testing and evaluation of the SPIE rig. After a few test dummies were tried, Marine Major Bruce F. Meyers, along with four Navy NPU parachutist engineers, successfully attempted the first flight on the SPIE assembly.
==See also== * [[Helicopter Rope Suspension Technique]] <!-- Reference citation needed at end of history
See: 1st Force Reconnaissance Company, Command Chronology, 1969 (recorded by month) US Marine Corps History Division Vietnam War Documents Collection, the Vietnam Center and Archive, Texas Tech University
Patrol reports cite numerous instances of use of SPIE to extract when helo sit-down or ramp touchdown not possible. -->
