{{About|the [[Smalltalk]] dialect|the concurrent programming languages from Bell Labs|Newsqueak|the children's TV show|Squeak!|the Doctor Who character|Survival (Doctor Who)|the general meaning of the word|Wiktionary:squeak}}
{{Infobox programming language | name = Squeak | logo = [[File:Squeak.svg|100px]] | logo caption = Original 1996 logo by Tim Rowledge<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rowledge.org/tim/squeak/ |title=Tim: Squeak Smalltalk |accessdate=2016-02-28}}</ref> | screenshot = [[File:Squeak-x11.png|225px]] | screenshot caption = [[Screenshot]] of a Squeak application running under [[X Window System|X11]]. | paradigm = [[Object-oriented programming|object-oriented]] | year = {{Start date and age|1996}} | designers = [[Alan Kay]], [[Dan Ingalls]], [[Adele Goldberg (computer scientist)|Adele Goldberg]] | developers = Alan Kay, Dan Ingalls, Ted Kaehler, Scott Wallace, John Maloney, Andreas Raab, Mike Rueger | latest release version = 5.2b | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2018|10|19}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.squeak.org/squeak/6599 |title=5.2 Release Notes}}</ref> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|2016|MM|DD}} --> | typing = [[Type system|Dynamic]] | implementations = Squeak, [[Croquet Project|Croquet]] | dialects = [[Pharo]], [[Croquet Project|Croquet]] | influenced by = [[Smalltalk]], [[Lisp (programming language)|Lisp]], [[Logo (programming language)|Logo]]; [[Sketchpad]], [[Simula]]; [[Self (programming language)|Self]] | influenced = [[Etoys (programming language)|Etoys]], Tweak, [[Croquet Project|Croquet]], [[Scratch (programming language)|Scratch]] | platform = [[Cross-platform]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]]: [[Unix-like]], [[macOS]], [[iOS]], [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], more | license = [[MIT License|MIT]], [[Apache License|Apache]] | website = {{URL|www.squeak.org}} }}
The '''Squeak''' [[programming language]] is a dialect of [[Smalltalk]]. It is [[object-oriented programming|object-oriented]], [[class (computer science)|class-based]], and [[reflection (computer programming)|reflective]].
It was derived directly from Smalltalk-80 by a group at [[Apple Inc.|Apple Computer]] that included some of the original Smalltalk-80 developers. Its development was continued by the same group at [[Walt Disney Imagineering]], where it was intended for use in internal Disney projects. Later on the group moved on to be supported by HP labs, SAP Labs and most recently [[Y Combinator (company) | Y Combinator]].
Squeak is [[cross-platform]]. Programs produced on one platform run bit-identical on all other platforms, and versions are available for many platforms including the obvious Windows/macOS/linux versions. The Squeak system includes code for generating a new version of the [[virtual machine]] (VM) on which it runs. It also includes a VM simulator written in Squeak. For these reasons, it is easily [[Porting|ported]].
==Developers== [[Dan Ingalls]], an important contributor to the Squeak project, wrote the paper<ref>{{cite web|url=http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=263754&coll=portal&dl=ACM |first=Dan |last=Ingalls |first2=Ted |last2=Kaehler |first3=John |last3=Maloney |first4=Scott |last4=Wallace |first5=Alan |last5=Kay |title=Back to the Future: the story of Squeak, a practical Smalltalk written in itself |publisher=ACM Digital Library |year=1997 |accessdate=2011-06-12}}</ref> upon which Squeak is built and constructed the architecture for five generations of the Smalltalk language.
Squeak incorporates many of the elements [[Alan Kay]] proposed in the [[Dynabook]] concept, which he formulated in the 1960s. Kay is an important contributor to the Squeak project.
==User interface frameworks== Squeak includes four [[user interface]] frameworks: * An implementation of [[Morphic (software)|Morphic]], [[Self (programming language)|Self's]] graphical [[direct manipulation interface]] framework. This is Squeak's main interface. * Tile-based, limited [[visual programming language|visual programming]] scripting in [[Etoys (programming language)|Etoys]], based on Morphic. * A novel, experimental interface called [[Tweak programming environment|Tweak]]. In 2001 it became clear that the Etoy architecture in Squeak had reached its limits in what the Morphic interface infrastructure could do. Hewlett-Packard researcher Andreas Raab proposed defining a "script process" and providing a default scheduling-mechanism that avoids several more general problems.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tweakproject.org/ABOUT/FAQ/OriginalTweakMemo/ |title=Tweak: OriginalTweakMemo |publisher=Tweakproject.org |date=2001-07-06 |accessdate=2011-06-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002012532/http://tweakproject.org/ABOUT/FAQ/OriginalTweakMemo/ |archivedate=2011-10-02 |df= }}</ref> This resulted in a new user interface, proposed to replace the Squeak Morphic user interface in the future. Tweak added mechanisms of islands, asynchronous messaging, players and costumes, language extensions, projects, and tile scripting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tweakproject.org/TECHNOLOGY/Whitepapers/ |title=Tweak: Whitepapers |publisher=Tweakproject.org |date= |accessdate=2011-06-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002012629/http://tweakproject.org/TECHNOLOGY/Whitepapers/ |archivedate=2011-10-02 |df= }}</ref> Its underlying object system is class-based, but to users, during programming (scripting), it acts like it is [[prototype-based programming|prototype-based]]. Tweak objects are created and run in Tweak project windows. * A [[model–view–controller]] (MVC) interface was the primary UI in Squeak versions 3.8 and earlier. It derived from the original Smalltalk-80 user interface framework which first introduced and popularized the MVC architectural pattern.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://st-www.cs.uiuc.edu/users/smarch/st-docs/mvc.html |first=Steve |last=Burbeck |title=How to use Model-View-Controller (MVC) |publisher=St-www.cs.uiuc.edu |date=1997-04-04 |accessdate=2011-06-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090801040629/http://st-www.cs.uiuc.edu/users/smarch/st-docs/mvc.html |archivedate=2009-08-01 |df= }}</ref> MVC takes its name from the three core classes of the framework. Thus, the term "MVC" in the context of Squeak refers to both one of the available user interface frameworks and the pattern the framework follows. MVC is still provided for programmers who wished to use this older type of interface.
==Uses== Many Squeak contributors collaborate on [[Open Cobalt]], a [[free software|free]] and [[open-source software|open source]] [[virtual world]] browser and construction toolkit application which is built on Squeak.
Squeak is also used in the Nintendo ES operating system<ref name="gamasutra">{{ cite web | title = Inside Nintendo's ES Open-Source Operating System | url = http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=16503 | publisher = Gamasutra | date = 2007-12-04| accessdate = 2007-12-05 }}</ref> and for implementing the [[Scratch (programming language)|Scratch]] programming language for beginning programmers. In May 2011 the [[OpenQwaq]] virtual conferencing and collaboration system based on Squeak, an open source release of Teleplace, was announced on the Teleplace blog.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Moving Immersive Collaboration Forward|url=http://teleplace.wordpress.com/2011/05/03/moving-immersive-collaboration-forward/}}</ref>
==License== Squeak 4.0 and later may be downloaded at no cost, including source code, as a prebuilt [[virtual machine]] image licensed under the [[MIT License]], with the exception of some of the original Apple code, which is governed by the [[Apache License]].
Originally, Apple actually released Squeak under a license called the ''Squeak License''. While source code was available and modification permitted, the Squeak License contained an [[indemnity clause]] that prevented it from qualifying as true [[free and open-source software]].
In 2006, Apple [[Software relicensing|relicensed]] Squeak twice. First, in May, Apple used its own [[Apple Public Source License]], which satisfies the [[Free Software Foundation]]'s concept of a Free Software License<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/apsl.html |title=FSF's Opinion on the Apple Public Source License (APSL) 2.0 |publisher=Gnu.org |date=2011-05-07 |accessdate=2011-06-12}}</ref> and has attained official approval from the [[Open Source Initiative]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opensource.org/pressreleases/osi-clarifies-APSL.php |title=Clarification of the APSL: Press Releases OS Clarifies The Status Of The APSL |publisher=Opensource.org |date=1999-03-17 |accessdate=2011-06-12}}</ref> as an Open Source License. The Apple Public Source License, as it turns out, fails to pass the third standard that Free and Open Source Software licenses are held to: the [[Debian Free Software Guidelines]] promulgated by the [[Debian]] project, an influential volunteer-run [[Linux]] distribution. To enable inclusion of [[Etoys (programming language)|Etoys]] in the [[One Laptop Per Child]] project, a second relicensing was undertaken using the Apache License. At this point, an effort was also made to address the issue of code contributed by members of the Squeak community, which it was not in Apple's power to unilaterally relicense.
For each contribution made under the Squeak License since 1996, a relicensing statement was obtained authorizing distribution under the [[MIT license]], and finally in March 2010, the end result was released as Squeak 4.0, now under combined MIT and Apache licenses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.h-online.com/open/news/item/Squeak-4-0-released-now-under-MIT-Apache-license-956267.html |publisher=The H Open |title=Squeak 4.0 released - now under MIT/Apache license |date=2010-03-16 |accessdate=2011-06-12}}</ref>
== Squeak virtual machine == {{refimprove|date=July 2016}} The ''Squeak virtual machine'' is a family of [[virtual machine]]s (VMs) used in [[Smalltalk]] programming language implementations. They are an essential part of any Smalltalk implementation. All are [[open-source software]]. The current VM is a high performance dynamic translation system. The relevant code is maintained on GitHub at [https://github.com/OpenSmalltalk/opensmalltalk-vm.git OpenSmalltalk]
===External links=== *[http://www.mirandabanda.org/cogblog/about-cog/ CogVM] *[http://stefan-marr.de/tag/roarvm/ RoarVM]
==See also== {{Portal|Free software}} * [[List of open-source programming languages]] * [[Alice (software)]] * [[Croquet Project]] * [[Pharo]] * [[Seaside (software)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|www.squeak.org}} * {{Dmoz|Computers/Programming/Languages/Smalltalk/Squeak}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Suman Sahai | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | residence = | nationality = [[India]]n | citizenship = India | education = [[Ph.D.]], 1975 | alma_mater =[[Indian Agricultural Research Institute]] | occupation = Founding director | years_active = | employer = | organization = [[Gene Campaign]] | known_for = | awards = [[Order of the Golden Ark]], [[Borlaug Award]], [[Padma Shri]] | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> }} '''Suman Sahai''' is an [[India]]n [[activist]] and the founder of [[Gene Campaign]].
==Career== Sahai obtained a [[Ph.D.]] from the [[Indian Agricultural Research Institute]]<ref name="intoday1">{{cite news |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/How+I+made+it:+Suman+Sahai/1/95201.html |title=How I made it: Suman Sahai : Aspire |work=[[India Today]] |date=2010-04-29 |accessdate=2013-03-29}}</ref> in 1975. She then successively worked at the [[University of Alberta]], [[University of Chicago]], and the [[University of Heidelberg]], where she obtained her [[habilitation]] in [[human genetics]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldacademy.org/view/nomination/3916 |title=Dr Suman Sahai: Curriculum vitae |publisher=[[World Academy of Art and Science]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FpNPa4sP?url=http://www.worldacademy.org/view/nomination/3916 |archivedate=12 April 2013 |accessdate=2013-04-12 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> According to the [[Web of Science]], Sahai has published over 40 articles, mostly on policy issues relating to [[genetically modified organism]]s, which have been cited over 150 times, giving her an [[h-index]] of 7.<ref>[[Web of Science]], accessed 2013-03-29.</ref> She is director of the [[NGO]], Gene Campaign.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/nj7215-1002a |title=Making a difference |year=2008 |last1=Basu |first1=Paroma |last2=Qiu |first2=Jane |last3=Powell |first3=Kendall |journal=Nature |volume=455 |issue=7215 |pages=1002–3 |pmid=18938259}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/nbt1102-1069 |title=Poor crop management plagues Bt cotton experiment in India |year=2002 |last1=Jayaraman |first1=K.S. |journal=Nature Biotechnology |volume=20 |issue=11 |pages=1069 |pmid=12410241}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/361291a0 |title=Indians protest against US-led gene bank |year=1993 |journal=Nature |volume=361 |issue=6410 |pages=291 |pmid=<!--none--> | bibcode = 1993Natur.361..291J |last1=Jayaraman |first1=K.S. }}</ref>
==Awards== * [[Order of the Golden Ark]], 2001<ref name="intoday1"/> * [[Borlaug Award]], 2004<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2004/01/31/stories/2004013106441200.htm |title=Subba Rao, Suman Sahai get Borlaug award |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=2004-01-31 |accessdate=2013-03-29}}</ref> * [[Padma Shri]], 2011<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=69364 |title=Press Information Bureau English Releases: Padma Awards Announced |publisher=Government of India |accessdate=2013-03-29}}</ref>
==Plagiarism== In April 2013, Sahai was shown to have committed [[plagiarism]] in her habilitation thesis,<ref name=LJ>{{cite journal |last=Köppelle |first=Winfried |title=Heidelberger Habilitations-Humbug |journal=Laborjournal |date=2013-04-09 |issue=4 |pages=14–17 |language=German |issn=1612-8354 |oclc=85726582 |url=http://www.biotech-europe.de/editorials/726.lasso |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FyZ4VTKp?url=http://www.biotech-europe.de/editorials/726.lasso |archivedate=18 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} [http://www.ask-force.org/web/India/Koeppelle-Heidelberg-Habilitation-Humbug-english-20130418.pdf English translation]</ref> which had been submitted to the University of Heidelberg in 1986.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://katalog.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/titel/2547898 |title=Sahai, Suman: Elucidation of the role of neurotransmitter glutamate in normal and abnormal mental function |publisher=University Library Heidelberg |work=HEIDI |accessdate=2013-04-12}}</ref> In addition, she was accused of presenting herself as being or having been a [[professor]] at that University, without ever actually having occupied such a position.<ref name=LJ /> On 14 April 2013, the University of Heidelberg confirmed that plagiarism had taken place, that Sahai has no right to call herself a professor of the University of Heidelberg, and that in consequence Sahai had agreed to renounce her ''[[venia legendi]]''.<ref name=LJ /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.klinikum.uni-heidelberg.de/ShowSingleNews.176.0.html?&no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=6772&cHash=493fc2a4bdbf14a5532b76df14417abd |title=Stellungnahme der Medizinischen Fakultät der Universität Heidelberg |archivedate=29 April 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GF0gCou9?url=http://www.klinikum.uni-heidelberg.de/ShowSingleNews.176.0.html?&no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5btt_news%5d=6772&cHash=493fc2a4bdbf14a5532b76df14417abd |publisher=UniversitätsKlinikum Heidelberg |accessdate=2013-04-29 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Scientific misconduct]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}}

{{good article}} {{Infobox person | name = Napoleon and Tabitha D'umo | image = Tabitha Dumo.jpg | alt = A strong Filipino man in a brown suit poses for a picture with his Italian wife who is wearing a colorful zebra print dress. | caption = Backstage after the 'So You Think You Can Dance' season four finale. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|10|17}} [Napoleon]
{{Birth date and age|1973|09|11}} [Tabitha] | agent = McDonald Selznick Associates{{cite web|title=Napoleon and Tabitha D'umo|url=http://www.msaagency.com/nappytabs/|work=MSAagency.com|accessdate=May 28, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cmbia5SA?url=http://www.msaagency.com/nappytabs/|archivedate=December 9, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} | home_town = [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], Nevada | children = 1{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Zack|title=Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo Welcome Son London Riley!|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo-welcome-son-london-riley-2012118|work=[[Us Weekly]]|date=August 11, 2012|accessdate=August 11, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014170148/http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo-welcome-son-london-riley-2012118|archivedate=October 14, 2012}} | known_for = Developing lyrical hip-hop | alma_mater = [[University of Las Vegas|University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] | residence = [[Sherman Oaks, California]]{{cite news|last=Wolfson|first=Julie|title=Talking about the Impact of Dance with Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo of So You Think You Can Dance|date=September 9, 2009|work=LAist.com|url=http://laist.com/2009/09/09/the_world_of_hip_hop_dnace_with_tab.php|accessdate=September 11, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwJr?url=http://laist.com/2009/09/09/the_world_of_hip_hop_dnace_with_tab.php|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} | other_names = Nappytabs | occupation = Choreographers, dance teachers, creative directors, entrepreneurs | years_active = 1996–present | awards = {{Awards|award=Outstanding Choreography|year=2014|title=So You Think You Can Dance|name=
Primetime Emmy Award}} {{Awards|award=Outstanding Choreography|year=2011|title=So You Think You Can Dance|name=
Primetime Emmy Award}} }} '''Tabitha A. D'umo''' ([[Married and maiden names|née]] '''Cortopassi'''; born September 11, 1973) and '''Napoleon Buddy D'umo''' (born October 17, 1968), known together as '''Nappytabs''', are [[Primetime Emmy Award|Emmy Award]]-winning married [[choreographer]]s who are often credited with developing ''lyrical'' hip-hop. They are best known for their choreography on the television show ''[[So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. TV series)|So You Think You Can Dance]]'' and for being supervising choreographers and executive producers of ''[[America's Best Dance Crew]]''. Since being with the former, their choreography has received both praise and criticism. They own Nappytabs urban dancewear and have been working in the dance industry since 1996. Tabitha and Napoleon grew up on opposite coasts of the United States and met in the early 1990s as students at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. They began their dance career together while still in college by choreographing [[industrial musicals]] for large corporations with the [[hip-hop dance]] company Culture Shock. After moving to Los Angeles in 1999, they started teaching hip-hop classes at the Edge Performing Arts Center. They took additional jobs choreographing for professional sports dance teams and back-up dancing for musical artists. In 2003, they joined the faculty of Monsters of Hip Hop dance convention. Their work was introduced to mainstream audiences in 2008 when they became supervising choreographers on ''America's Best Dance Crew'' and resident choreographers on ''So You Think You Can Dance''. It was on the later show that their lyrical hip-hop choreography style gained exposure. The pair's career progressed to providing creative direction for tours and live events by Christina Aguilera, Ricky Martin, Celine Dion, and Jennifer Lopez. They continued to develop their dancewear line by breaking out of its previously online-only presence and opening a physical store location in 2010. From television and concerts, their move into theater occurred gradually. In 2010, they directed the [[JabbaWockeeZ]]'s ''MÜS.I.C.'' stage show and began to work with [[Cirque du Soleil]]; they choreographed ''[[Viva Elvis]]'' and were contributing choreographers for ''[[Michael Jackson: The Immortal World Tour]]''. They continued to establish themselves in television as choreographers for [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s [[Super Bowl]] halftime performance. By 2015, they had choreographed several [[K-pop]] music videos for artists such as [[TVXQ]], [[Exo (band)|EXO]], and [[BoA]]. Aside from their choreography, creative direction, and dancewear line, Tabitha and Napoleon continue to teach hip-hop classes at dance studios and on the convention circuit. They have also been involved with charity work for organizations that support the arts. ==Life and career== ===1968–1996: Early life and education=== Napoleon was born October 17, 1968. He was raised in [[Victorville, California]] as one of three siblings.{{cite web|url=http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs023/1102748757093/archive/1103533309141.html|title=Issue #9|date=July 2010|work=ConstantContact.com|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s9pyAoUW?url=http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs023/1102748757093/archive/1103533309141.html|archivedate=August 21, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} He learned [[b-boying]], [[Locking (dance)|locking]], and [[popping (dance)|popping]] by traveling to Los Angeles and frequenting the [[b-boy]] scene; he was eventually cast as an extra in the movie ''[[Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloo]]'' in 1984.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Jen|title=Hollywood's Hot Dancing Duo, Tabitha and Napoleon D'Umo|work=Dance Teacher|url=http://www.dance-teacher.com/content/hollywoods-hot-dancing-duo-tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo|accessdate=April 20, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjvDxx6?url=http://www.dance-teacher.com/content/feature-hollywoods-hot-dancing-duo-tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} After Napoleon graduated from [[Apple Valley High School (California)|Apple Valley High School]],{{cite av media|people= Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo (interviewees)|date=October 8, 2009|url=http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/2317200|title=SYTYCDism Live Chat with Napoleon and Tabitha D'Umo|type=Podcast|location=Los Angeles|publisher=SYTYCDism|accessdate=May 9, 2010|time=56:50}} he joined the army{{cite podcast|url=http://infinitedancecast.com/?p=294|title=Episode 24 – Nappytabs Interview|website=InfiniteDanceCast.com|publisher=Nick & Desiree’s Infinite Dance Cast|host=Nick Drago and Desiree Robbins|date=October 10, 2011|accessdate=October 16, 2011}}{{Rp|13:57}} and worked as a surgeon's assistant while stationed in Germany.{{cite news|title=MH Interview: Napoleon D'Umo|url=http://www.menshealth.com.sg/guy-wisdom/mh-interview-napoleon-dumo|work=[[Men's Health (magazine)|Men's Health]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zaNxiwSI?url=http://www.menshealth.com.sg/guy-wisdom/mh-interview-napoleon-dumo|archivedate=June 20, 2011|accessdate=June 20, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} Once discharged, he attended the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] (UNLV) where he majored in [[molecular biology]]{{cite web|title=Choreographed Careers|url=http://vegasseven.com/ae/2010/november/18/choreographed-careers|work=VegasSeven.com|date=November 18, 2010|accessdate=July 21, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224111415/http://vegasseven.com/2010/11/18/choreographed-careers/|archivedate=February 24, 2014|quote='We’re known for this 'lyrical hip-hop' genre now,' Napoleon, 42, says. 'That definitely came straight from competing with the Vegas industry. We had to think about the audience and what they wanted. So that’s when we really started honing all our skills for storytelling because we had to make it entertaining.'}} and started taking [[jazz dance|jazz]] and [[modern dance|modern]] dance classes. Tabitha was born September 11, 1973, and grew up as an only child in [[Galloway Township, New Jersey]].{{cite news|last=Cronick|first=Scott|title=Everyone has a story: Galloway woman choreographs 'Rockin' Eve'|date=December 30, 2009|work=[[The Press of Atlantic City]]|url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/blogs/scott_cronick/article_cdfe9a4e-f53d-11de-8766-001cc4c002e0.html|accessdate=February 27, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwKh?url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/blogs/scott_cronick/article_cdfe9a4e-f53d-11de-8766-001cc4c002e0.html|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Her mother enrolled her in jazz dance classes when she was young. Since there were no hip-hop classes, Tabitha learned by watching music videos and participating in her school's [[cheerleader|cheer]] and dance teams. She cites [[Michael Jackson]], [[Janet Jackson]], and [[Paula Abdul]] as influences. While cheerleading at Absegami High School, Tabitha earned "All-American" status at an [[National Cheerleaders Association|NCA]] camp and got the opportunity to perform in the [[Aloha Bowl]] in Hawaii.{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Jen|date=June 2010|title=Keeping Tabs on Nappytabs|journal=American Cheerleader|volume=16|issue=3|page=31|quote='I was there hanging out with a bunch of buff bodybuilders, and Tabitha and her friends invited us to come and stunt with them sometime,' remembers Napoleon. The next day, the crew headed to a nearby lake to boat, jet ski and cheer—and the rest was history. Napoleon and the boys attended a practice, where they wowed the team's coach and snagged full-ride scholarships to join the team.}} After Tabitha graduated, she moved to Nevada in 1991{{cite news|last=Padgett|first=Sonya|url=http://www.lvrj.com/neon/a-long-road-to-fame-96546704.html|title=Dancing to Their Own Tune: A Long Road to Fame|date=June 17, 2010|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPNr?url=http://www.lvrj.com/neon/jabbawockeez-93757434.html|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} to attend UNLV where she majored in communications and started taking formal hip-hop dance classes. It was there at a party that she met Napoleon. While hanging out with her cheerleading and dance team friends, Tabitha invited Napoleon and his body building friends to come to a casual practice session and do [[List of cheerleading stunts|stunt work]] with them. Napoleon and his friends eventually attended a formal practice session on campus, and the cheerleading coach was so impressed with their work that they all received full scholarships to join the team. Tabitha and Napoleon started dating in 1994, but their professional partnership and dance career did not start until 1996 when they began teaching hip-hop classes together at the Las Vegas Athletic Club. Since the beginning of their career, they have always worked together including their first choreography job and the first dance class they taught.{{cite podcast|url=http://www.onlinedanceacademy.com/oda/podcast/source/TabNab_AmerBestDanceRockReception.mp3|title=America's Favorite Choreography Duo - Tabitha of Tabitha & Napoleon D'umo|website=OnlineDanceAcademy.com |publisher=Tap In with Laurie Johnson|host=Laurie Johnson|accessdate=April 19, 2009}} ===1996–2007: Early career, dancewear, and creative directing=== While Tabitha and Napoleon were still in college, they were accepted into the dance company Culture Shock where they met members of the [[JabbaWockeeZ]] before the JabbaWockeeZ became a crew. In addition to going to school and being a part of Culture Shock, they both maintained part-time jobs. Together they worked at Bunker Dance Center in Las Vegas teaching hip-hop classes.{{cite web|title=Red Carpet: Hall of Fame|url=http://bunkerdancecenter.com/redcarpet/?page=halloffame|work=BunkerDanceCenter.com|accessdate=February 16, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65UwHP694?url=http://bunkerdancecenter.com/redcarpet/?page=halloffame|archivedate=February 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} Separately Napoleon worked as a personal trainer and Tabitha worked at the [[Rio All Suite Hotel and Casino|Rio Hotel and Casino]]. While dancing with Culture Shock, Tabitha created [[Reel#Demo reels|demo reels]] of the company to send to event organizers who were having conventions in Las Vegas.{{cite web|url=http://swiggtalk.com/blogs/be-strong/tabitha-dumo-so-you-think-you-can-dance|work=SwiggTalk.com|title=Tabitha D'umo: So You Think You Can Dance|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPLM?url=http://swiggtalk.com/blogs/be-strong/tabitha-dumo-so-you-think-you-can-dance|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Tabitha and Napoleon used this method to book choreography jobs and it was during this time that they honed their lyrical hip-hop style. Through Culture Shock, they were hired to choreograph several [[industrial musical]]s for casinos and corporations such as Nike, Levi, Redken, Matrix Hair, and [[Make-up Art Cosmetics|MAC]].{{cite web|title=Faculty|url=http://shocktheintensive.com/faculty/#faculty|work=ShocktheIntensive.com|accessdate=April 19, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwKw?url=http://shocktheintensive.com/faculty/|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} They eventually worked their way up from company dancers to become the artistic directors. As Tabitha and Napoleon's college graduation was approaching they decided to change their plans from a job in public relations and medical school respectively to a career in the dance industry. Tabitha and Napoleon were married April 19, 1998. In 1999, they moved to Los Angeles to expand their opportunities. Upon arriving in L.A., they taught hip-hop classes at the Edge Performing Arts Center.{{cite web|last=Feller|first=Alison|title=L.A. Confidential|url=http://www.dancespirit.com/articles/2343|work=Dance Spirit|date=November 14, 2009|accessdate=August 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPLW?url=http://www.dancespirit.com/articles/2343|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} They found extra work as back-up dancers for [[Beyoncé]], [[Toni Braxton]], [[Missy Elliott]], [[Monica (entertainer)|Monica]], [[Timbaland]], [[Sisqó]], and [[Destiny's Child]] whom they went on tour with in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.xtremedanceforce.com/directors/guestchoreographers.asp|title=Guest Choreographers|work=XtremeDanceForce.com|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62UFfVPap?url=http://www.xtremedanceforce.com/directors/guestchoreographers.asp|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite journal|last=Gdula|first=Kimberly|title=Nine Lives|journal=Dance Spirit|date=November 2002|volume=6|issue=9|pages=54|quote=Napoleon and Tabitha recently got off the Destiny's Child World Tour. Both teach hip hop at the EDGE, LADF conventions and the Millennium Dance Complex.}} Their move from dancing into choreography occurred gradually. Jobs included choreographing performances for [[NFL]] and [[NBA]] dance teams including the Dallas Cowboys, Denver Broncos, Chicago Bulls, and Orlando Magic.{{cite web|title=Monsters of Hip Hop at The Ailey Extension|url=https://www.signup4.net/public/ap.aspx?EID=MONS82E&OID=50|work=signup4.net|accessdate=April 2, 2010}} In November 2002, they made the cover of ''Dance Spirit'' magazine. They were profiled with seven other choreographers and interviewed about what it takes to make it as a dancer in Los Angeles. In 2003, Napoleon started teaching classes with Monsters of Hip Hop dance convention.{{cite web|url=http://www.dance.com/mag/october-2003/47/inside-dance-hiphop/2885|title=Monsters of HipHop Dance Workshop Announces Seven-City National Tour|work=Dance|date=October 2003|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPLf?url=http://www.dance.com/mag/october-2003/47/inside-dance-hiphop/2885/|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Tabitha joined him later and they are still permanent faculty members to this day.{{cite web|title=Monsters of Hip Hop bios|url=http://www.monstersofhiphop.com/#faculty|work=Monsters.com|accessdate=May 25, 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwMX?url=http://www.monstersofhiphop.com/faculty/|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} [[Image:Nappytabs.gif|thumb|right|200px|The original Nappytabs dancewear logo.|alt=A hazelnut and cream-colored yin-and-yang like symbol with the word "Nappytabs" printed underneath in capital letters.]] In 2005, Tabitha and Napoleon started Nappytabs dancewear. They cite the lack of appropriate dancewear for the hip-hop dance community as inspiration for the company.{{Cite journal|last=Krisanits|first=Tracy|date=March 2007|title=Keeping Tabs|journal=Dance Retailer News|issue=5|page=46}}{{cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Kristy|date=June 2009|title=Tabitha and Napoleon Exclusive!|work=Dance Informa|issue=15|url=http://www.danceinforma.com/EZINE15_Tabitha_Napoleon.html|accessdate=June 8, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwM5?url=http://www.danceinforma.com/EZINE15_Tabitha_Napoleon.html|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{Cite journal|last=Jones|first=Jen|date=November 2008|title=Seeing Double|journal=Dance Teacher|page=52}} Early in its production, Tabitha sewed the clothes herself.{{cite web|author=Dasha Dahl|url=http://dancerussia.ru/publication/114.html|title=Nappytabs: Dance From the Heart|work=DanceRussia.ru|accessdate=August 8, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62T3Bvchy?url=http://dancerussia.ru/publication/114.html|archivedate=October 16, 2011|language=ru|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite av media|people=Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo (interviewees)|date=October 8, 2009|url=http://www.ustream.tv/recorded/2317200|title=SYTYCDism Live Chat with Napoleon and Tabitha D'Umo|type=Podcast|location=Los Angeles|publisher=SYTYCDism|accessdate=May 9, 2010|time=22:40}} The Nappytabs logo began as a [[yin and yang]] like symbol with an "n" and a "t" overlapping in the middle. The word itself—Nappytabs—is a combination of Napoleon (Nappy) and Tabitha's (Tab) nicknames. Contrary to popular belief, the name 'Nappytabs' started as their clothing line first. They did not call themselves Nappytabs, and the word being a nickname to refer to both of them did not start until they became choreographers on ''So You Think You Can Dance''.{{Rp|16:12}} Tabitha and Napoleon began creative directing stage shows and concerts in the mid-2000s. In 2006, they served as assistant directors for [[Christina Aguilera]]’s ''[[Back to Basics Tour]]''. In 2007, they were also assistant directors for [[Ricky Martin]]’s ''[[Ricky Martin Live: Black & White Tour|Black and White Tour]]''. Both tours were directed by [[Jamie King]] who is known primarily for his work with [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]].{{cite news|last=Ryder|first=Caroline|date=July 20, 2011|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118040066|title=King aims large without sacrificing intimacy|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=November 21, 2011}} The same year, Tabitha appeared in two fitness DVDs. She was the host/instructor of ''Drop it with Dance''.{{cite av media|people=D'umo, Tabitha (host)|date=2007|title=Prevention Fitness Systems/Drop it with Dance|type=DVD|publisher=Rodale|location=New York City|isbn=0766234002|oclc=181376210}} The video is split into six 10-minute routines that gradually increase in difficulty; movements from all six routines are combined in the finale "Showtime" segment.{{cite web|last=Kaufmann|first=Jeffrey|date=January 5, 2008|title=Prevention Fitness Systems – Drop It with Dance|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/31917/prevention-fitness-systems-drop-it-with-dance|work=DVDtalk.com|accessdate=April 20, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwN6?url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/31917/prevention-fitness-systems-drop-it-with-dance/|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} She also appeared in ''Rock Your Body'', which was hosted by [[Jamie King]].{{cite av media|people=King, Jamie (host)|date=2007|title=Rock Your Body with Jaime King|type=DVD|publisher=Rodale|location=New York City|isbn=0766229300|oclc=129661559}} ===2008–2009: Dance shows and mainstream exposure=== Tabitha and Napoleon became supervising choreographers for the inaugural season of ''[[America's Best Dance Crew]]'' in 2008.{{cite news|last=Paloucek|first=Karl|title=MTV Puts More Than Four on the Floor|work=Zap2it.com|date=February 7, 2008|url=http://www.zap2it.com/tv/zap-story-randyjackson-americasbestdancecrew,0,7798247.story|accessdate=April 23, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62T3M5hSE?url=http://www.zap2it.com/tv/zap-story-randyjackson-americasbestdancecrew,0,7798247.story|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} They were responsible for choreographing group routines, coming up with dance challenges, and assisting the [[History of hip-hop dance#Dance crews|crews]] as needed with polishing their performances.{{cite web|url=http://remotecontrol.mtv.com/2010/03/22/choreographers-nappytabs-and-rosero-have-something-hot-cookin-in-the-oven|title=Choreographers Nappytabs and Rosero Have Something Hot Cookin' In The Oven|date=May 22, 2010|work=MTV.com|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPLx?url=http://remotecontrol.mtv.com/2010/03/22/choreographers-nappytabs-and-rosero-have-something-hot-cookin-in-the-oven/|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Also in 2008, they took on hosting duties for ''Rock the Reception''.{{cite news|last=Kinon|first=Cristina|title=Bride, groom ready to rhumba in 'Rock the Reception|work=Daily News|date=July 7, 2008|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2008/07/07/2008-07-07_bride_groom_ready_to_rhumba_in_rock_the_.html|accessdate=April 20, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwLW?url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2008/07/07/2008-07-07_bride_groom_ready_to_rhumba_in_rock_the_.html|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} On the show, they created wedding dances for engaged couples and their wedding party to perform at the reception. The participants were real life couples with no dance experience. In addition to ''America's Best Dance Crew'' and ''Rock the Reception'', they joined the choreography and judging team on the fourth season of ''[[So You Think You Can Dance (Season 4)|So You Think You Can Dance]]''.{{Cite journal|last=Cheng|first=Peter|date=October 2008|title=Lovers of Hip Hop|journal=Gloss Magazine|volume=1|issue=14|url=http://www.glossmag.ca/issues/14/arts/4-nappytabs.html|accessdate=April 4, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwKM?url=http://www.glossmag.ca/issues/14/arts/4-nappytabs.html|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} It was on this show that their lyrical hip-hop choreography style gained mainstream exposure. Lyrical hip-hop is a fluid and more interpretive version of standard hip-hop often danced to [[wikt:downtempo|downtempo]] rap music or R&B music. The term itself was coined by choreographer and producer [[Adam Shankman]] in reference to a routine choreographed by Tabitha and Napoleon to [[Leona Lewis]]' song "[[Bleeding Love]]". "Bleeding Love" was nominated for a 2009 Emmy Award for Outstanding Choreography.{{cite web|title=2009 Creative Arts Emmy Award nominees|url=http://www.emmys.com/nominations?tid=108|work=Emmys.com|accessdate=July 21, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwLr?url=http://www.emmys.com/nominations?tid=108|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} After the season ended, Tabitha and Napoleon directed the 2008 ''So You Think You Can Dance Tour''. They continued creative directing several other concerts throughout the remainder of the year. They teamed up with Jamie King again and served as assistant directors for [[Celine Dion]]'s ''[[Taking Chances Tour]].'' They directed ''Monsters of Hip Hop: The Show''{{cite web|date=August 2008|title=Tabitha and Napoleon, Monsters of the Show|work=Movmnt Magazine|url=http://www.movmnt.com/monsters-of-the-sho_001047.html|accessdate=June 11, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPM6?url=http://www.movmnt.com/monsters-of-the-sho_001047.html|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} and ''America's Best Dance Crew Live'' which featured dance crews JabbaWockeeZ, [[Super Cr3w]], [[Fanny Pak]], ASIID, and Breaksk8. OMG! gave the concert a positive review stating that the five crews represented a good mix of styles and that the concert brought the best parts of the show to the stage.{{cite news|last=Nguyen|first=Chrissy Le|url=http://omg.yahoo.com/blogs/crush/americas-best-dance-crew-live-tour-review/77|title='America's Best Dance Crew' Live Tour Review|work=omg.Yahoo.com|date=October 20, 2008|accessdate=July 31, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPMF?url=http://omg.yahoo.com/blogs/crush/americas-best-dance-crew-live-tour-review/77|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} In January 2009, the Nappytabs dancewear website launched which began the start of online clothing sales.{{cite web|url=http://community.intellicontact.com/p/nappytabs/newsletters/shoponline/posts/shop-online-at-nappytabscom|title=Shop online at Nappytabs.com|work=IntelliContact.com|date=January 31, 2009|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPMO?url=http://community.intellicontact.com/p/nappytabs/newsletters/shoponline/posts/shop-online-at-nappytabscom|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} The first version of their website was designed and maintained by Ryan Cyphert's 3nine Design media company.{{cite web|title=What We Do|url=http://3ninedesign.com|work=3ninedesign.com|accessdate=December 7, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CjuApggw?url=http://3ninedesign.com/|archivedate=December 7, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} Cyphert is also a professional dancer and a colleague of Tabitha and Napoleon. At the time the website launched they all were faculty members at Shock the Intensive dance convention. When Tabitha and Napoleon joined ''So You Think You Can Dance'', dancers on the show, as well as on ''America's Best Dance Crew'' and ''Dancing With the Stars'', were already wearing their clothing line during rehearsals. Some of the sponsors were not happy about it and wanted to cover the Nappytabs logo on the clothing. In response to this, judge and executive producer [[Nigel Lythgoe]] decided to start calling Tabitha and Napoleon "Nappytabs" during the show so that viewers who looked them up on Google would find their store's website.{{Rp|16:12}}{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/news/me-my-emmy/napoleon-and-tabitha-dumo|title=Napoleon and Tabitha D'umo|date=September 9, 2013|work=Emmy Magazine|quote=When we started our line, we came up with [the] name because people on the lot would call him Nappy and me, Tab. But when everyone began wearing our clothing on the show — and on Dancing with the Stars — somebody mentioned that there was a lot of Nappytabs clothing being seen. A sponsor didn't like it, so [SYTYCD executive producer and judge] Nigel [Lythgoe] said he was going to start calling us Nappytabs, so that whenever anyone Googled the name, our store site would come up. And it took off.|accessdate=September 28, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024023935/http://www.emmys.com/news/me-my-emmy/napoleon-and-tabitha-dumo|archivedate=October 24, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.lamag.com/laculture/culturefilesblog/2013/09/20/choreographing-couple-tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo-not-just-hip-hop-anymore|title=Choreographing Couple Tabitha and Napoleon Dumo: Not Just Hip-Hop Anymore|last=Camus|first=Renee|date=September 20, 2013|work=Los Angeles Magazine|accessdate=September 28, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926183552/http://www.lamag.com/laculture/culturefilesblog/2013/09/20/choreographing-couple-tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo-not-just-hip-hop-anymore|archivedate=September 26, 2013}} In April 2009, Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed two couples' routines and a group routine for the second season of ''[[So You Think You Can Dance Australia (season 2)|So You Think You Can Dance Australia]]''. The "[[Arab Money]]" hip-hop routine they choreographed received positive reviews from the judges but their "[[Dead and Gone]]" ''lyrical'' hip-hop routine, which was performed later on the same episode, received the most praise. [[Bonnie Lythgoe]] called it the "top routine of the night". Jason Coleman added "the choreography [was] absolutely spectacular" and Matt Lee said it was "...probably the best routine in the series."{{cite av media|people=Talia & BJ (dancers)|date=April 5, 2009|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pHisnm7K3qA|type=Television production|title=SYTYCD Australia: Top 6 – "Dead and Gone"|location=Sydney|publisher=FremantleMedia Australia Pty|accessdate=April 19, 2009}}{{cite episode|title=Top 6 Performance |series=So You Think You Can Dance Australia|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance Australia (season 2)|network=[[Network Ten]]|season=2|number=21}} While in Australia, Tabitha and Napoleon were judges at the 2009 Australian Hip Hop Championships in Sydney.{{cite web|title=AHC Sydney Finals – Review|url=http://www.criticalhype.com/news/ahc-syd-review|date=April 20, 2009|work=CriticalHype.com|accessdate=June 10, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qslJ4MxY?url=http://www.criticalhype.com/news/ahc-syd-review/|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed several television specials later in the year. In September, they choreographed the opening dance sequence on the season seven premiere of ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]''.{{cite episode|title=Season Premiere|series=The Ellen DeGeneres Show|serieslink=The Ellen DeGeneres Show|credits=Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo (choreographers)|network=[[broadcast syndication|syndicated]]|airdate=September 8, 2009|season=7|number=1}} The routine featured both DeGeneres and the top ten dancers from season five of ''So You Think You Can Dance''. At the [[61st Primetime Emmy Awards]], they choreographed a routine honoring dance{{cite web|title=Emmy Nominated Tabitha and Napoleon D'Uomo (sic) to Choreograph for Emmy's|url=http://movies.broadwayworld.com/article/Emmy_Nominated_Tabitha_and_Napoleon_DUomo_to_Choreograph_for_Emmys_20090916|date=September 16, 2009|work=BroadwayWorld.com|accessdate=February 14, 2010}} that featured [[Karina Smirnoff]] and [[Maksim Chmerkovskiy]] from ''Dancing With The Stars''; [[Katee Shean]], [[Mark Kanemura]], and [[Joshua Allen]] from ''So You Think You Can Dance''; and four members of [[Quest Crew]]—the winners of season three of ''America's Best Dance Crew''. They finished the year with choreography for [[Carrie Underwood]]'s ''All-Star Holiday Special'' and [[Jennifer Lopez]]' performance on ''[[Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve with Ryan Seacrest]]''. ===2010–2011: Stage productions and brand expansion=== In 2010, Tabitha and Napoleon returned to ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (SYTYCD) for season seven and started to work with four different productions of Cirque du Soleil. In February, they provided choreography for Cirque du Soleil's ''[[Viva Elvis]]'' show at the Aria hotel in Las Vegas.{{cite web |title=Meet the Creators of Viva ELVIS |url=http://www.cirquedusoleil.com/en/shows/viva-elvis/show/creators.aspx |work=CirqueDuSoleil.com |accessdate=March 5, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwLd?url=http://www.cirquedusoleil.com/en/shows/viva-elvis/show/creators.aspx |archivedate=June 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} They also choreographed a ''Viva Elvis'' guest appearance on ''Dancing with the Stars''.{{cite news|last=Bohen|first=Coleen|url=http://www.dancespirit.com/blogs/2609|title="Dancing With The Stars" Recap: Season 10, Week 7 Elimination|date=May 5, 2010|work=Dance Spirit|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPMY?url=http://www.dancespirit.com/blogs/2609|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} On SYTYCD, they choreographed routines for the contestants as well as one guest performance for the cast of Cirque du Soleil's ''[[Love (Cirque du Soleil)|Beatles Love]]''.{{cite news|last=Propst|first=Andy|url=http://www.theatermania.com/las-vegas/news/07-2010/cast-members-from-viva-elvis-to-perform-on-foxs-so_28566.html|title=Cast Members from Viva ELVIS to Perform on FOX's So You Think You Can Dance July 1|work=TheaterMania.com|date=July 1, 2010|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPMh?url=http://www.theatermania.com/las-vegas/news/07-2010/cast-members-from-viva-elvis-to-perform-on-foxs-so_28566.html|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} They worked with ''Love'' again at the [[National Hockey League#Trophies and awards|NHL awards]]{{cite news|url=http://www.fortsaskatchewanrecord.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=2658502&|title=McKinlay on stage at the NHL awards|work=Fort Saskatchewan Record|date=July 8, 2010|accessdate=August 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U1nSGMU?url=http://www.fortsaskatchewanrecord.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=2658502&&archive=true|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} and with their sister Cirque productions ''[[Kà]]'', for a guest performance on ''America's Got Talent'', and ''[[Mystère (Cirque du Soleil)|Mystère]]'', for a guest performance on ''[[Lopez Tonight]]''. After SYTYCD ended, they appeared as guest choreographers on the Ukrainian version of the show called ''Everybody Can Dance!/Танцюють всі!''.{{cite av media|title=NappyTabs at Dancers Alliance AFTRA Party - Talk about jabbawockeez & ABDC 6.0|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OtWsZNfhgwQ|type=Interview|date=November 27, 2010|time=2:08|accessdate=January 13, 2011}} {{external media|width=225px|video1=John Gillette's [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K0WCqLATxvQ "All Bad"] music video.}} Aside from choreography, Tabitha and Napoleon continued to develop and expand their dancewear line. In May, they opened the Nappytabs store and dance studio in the North Hollywood Arts District.{{cite web|last=Bianconi|first=Nancy|url=http://bvs.sld.cu/indice.php|title=Napoleon & Tabitha, Choreographers on "So You Think You Can Dance" Open Shop!|date=June 1, 2010|work=NohoArtsDistrict.com|accessdate=August 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U3OFH1h?option=com_content&view=article&id=721?url=http://bvs.sld.cu/indice.php|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs023/1102748757093/archive/1103375976947|title=Issue #7|date=May 2010|work=ConstantContact.com|accessdate=July 2, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qv27tkbQ?url=http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs023/1102748757093/archive/1103340121310.html|archivedate=July 2, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Although they design their own clothing, they commissioned some print and t-shirt designs from Alex Lodermeier who has also designed for Propr,{{cite web|title=Portfolio|url=http://www.1974design.com/portfolio.html|work=1974Design.com|accessdate=April 6, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rZDssSfu?url=http://www.1974design.com/portfolio.html|archivedate=July 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} a clothing line owned by [[Ben Harper]], [[David Arquette]], and David Bedwell.{{cite web|title=David Arquette’s Propr Clothing Collection|url=http://stylefrizz.com/200903/david-arquettes-propr-clothing-collection|work=StyleFrizz.com|accessdate=October 15, 2010}} Through Nappytabs, they also started to sponsor The Pulse on Tour dance convention{{cite web|url=http://www.thepulseontour.com/sponsors.html|work=ThePulseOnTour.com|title=Sponsors|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPN7?url=http://www.thepulseontour.com/sponsors.html|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} and the ''Industry Voice'' online newsletter.{{cite web|url=http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs023/1102748757093/archive/1103456621377.html|title=Issue #8|date=June 2010|work=ConstantContact.com|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s9pyAoVy?url=http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs023/1102748757093/archive/1103456621377.html|archivedate=August 21, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Their clothing appears in independent [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] singer John Gillette's music video "All Bad". Tabitha was a featured dancer in the video and Napoleon made a cameo appearance at the end. Also in May, the JabbaWockeeZ' ''MÜS.I.C.'' (pronounced [[Muse|MUSE]]-i-see) stage show, which Tabitha and Napoleon directed, opened at the MGM Grand Las Vegas hotel. ''MÜS.I.C.'' was the first hip-hop dance stage show on the [[Las Vegas Strip]].{{cite news|last=Palopoli|first=Steve|date=April 21, 2011|title=Fingerz on the Pulse|url=http://www.metroactive.com/features/the-bangerzs.html|work=MetroActive.com|accessdate=August 12, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U3lw24r?url=http://www.metroactive.com/features/the-bangerzs.html|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite journal|last=Sagolla|first=Lisa Jo|date=August 5, 2011|title=Dancing with the Jabbawockeez: Jeff 'Phi' Nguyen reveals what it's like to be part of a genuinely collaborative dance enterprise|journal=Back Stage, National ed.|volume=51|issue=31|page=17|quote=The seven-member, all-male, Los Angeles-based hip-hop dance troupe known as Jabbawockeez is a highly unusual organization. But it is not the austere white masks and mysterious white gloves the performers always wear onstage that make it so unusual. Nor is it the strange name, which is derived from that of the title character, a dragonlike creature, in the [[Lewis Carroll]] nonsense poem "Jabberwocky." And neither is it the company's distinction as the first dance crew to ever headline its own show in Las Vegas. What makes Jabbawockeez a truly rare dance troupe are the communal sensibility and the collaborative practices that drive everything about how the group is run and how its work is created and presented.}} The show was 90 minutes long involving dancing, comedy, and magic.{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Larsen|url=http://www.ocregister.com/entertainment/says-246560-going-chung.html|title=UCI grad reaches Vegas stardom with Jabbawockeez|work=The Orange County Register|date=April 29, 2010|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPNY?url=http://www.ocregister.com/entertainment/says-246560-going-chung.html|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} In October, ''MÜS.I.C.'' moved to the Monte Carlo Resort and Casino.{{cite news|last=Weatherford|first=Mike|url=http://www.lvrj.com/blogs/vegasvoice/ENTERTAINMENT_Jabbawockeez_dance_into_Monte_Carlo.html?ref=919|title=ENTERTAINMENT: Jabbawockeez dance into Monte Carlo|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|date=September 7, 2010|accessdate=September 18, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U3wGUX7?url=http://www.lvrj.com/blogs/vegasvoice/ENTERTAINMENT_Jabbawockeez_dance_into_Monte_Carlo.html?ref=919|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} At the Monte Carlo premiere, the JabbaWockeeZ brought Tabitha on stage for a cameo appearance. [[Image:Nappytabs IRIS.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Tabitha and Napoleon in 2011 at the world premiere of [[Iris (Cirque du Soleil)|Iris]] by Cirque du Soleil.]] In February 2011, Tabitha and Napoleon made their music video directorial debut with the song "All These Boys" by [[Jasmine Villegas]]. Unlike John Gillette's "All Bad" they did not dance or appear in the video, but they did serve as the choreographers.{{cite web|last=Adickman|first=Erika|title=Behind The Scenes Of Jasmine V.’s "All These Boys" Music Video|url=http://idolator.com/5746871/jasmine-v-all-these-boys-music-video|work=Idolator.com|date=January 21, 2011|accessdate=February 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U4xiMHh?url=http://idolator.com/5746871/jasmine-v-all-these-boys-music-video|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} In the Spring, they returned to working in television with two projects. At the invitation of Nigel Lythgoe, they joined the production crew on the tenth season of ''[[American Idol]]'' as [[Staging (theatre)|staging]] and creative directors,{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodoutbreak.com/2011/04/20/tabitha-and-napoleon-d%E2%80%99umo-%E2%80%93-teaching-pro-moves-to-%E2%80%9Cidol%E2%80%9D-contestants|title=Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo - Teaching Pro Moves to "Idol" Contestants|date=April 20, 2010|work=HollywoodOutbreak.com|accessdate=June 14, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U5D8WgT?url=http://www.hollywoodoutbreak.com/2011/04/20/tabitha-and-napoleon-d%E2%80%99umo-%E2%80%93-teaching-pro-moves-to-%E2%80%9Cidol%E2%80%9D-contestants/|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} a position they continued to hold for season 11. They also choreographed the [[Howie Mandel]]-produced television show ''[[Mobbed (TV series)|Mobbed]]'' which premiered after ''American Idol'' on March 31, 2011.{{cite web|title=Napoleon and Tabitha D'umo - Loving the "MOBBED" Mentality|url=http://www.hollywoodoutbreak.com/2011/03/31/napoleon-and-tabitha-dumo-loving-the-%E2%80%9Cmobbed%E2%80%9D-mentality|work=HollywoodOutbreak.com|date=March 31, 2011|accessdate=April 11, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U63IMaC?url=http://www.hollywoodoutbreak.com/2011/03/31/napoleon-and-tabitha-dumo-loving-the-%E2%80%9Cmobbed%E2%80%9D-mentality/|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} The pilot episode was actually shot in September 2010,{{cite web|first=Juelz|last=Sanchez|title=MOBBED: Howie Mandel’s Hidden Camera Dance Show with NAPPYTABS|url=http://hollywoodjunket.com/2010/09/20/mobbed-howie-mandels-hidden-camera-dance-show-with-nappytabs|work=HollywoodJunket.com|accessdate=November 29, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U6BL1oL?url=http://hollywoodjunket.com/2010/09/20/mobbed-howie-mandels-hidden-camera-dance-show-with-nappytabs/|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} but after drawing 10.8 million views it was picked up as a series.{{cite web|last=Ng|first=Philiana|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/fox-orders-howie-mandels-mobbed-173996|title=Fox Orders Howie Mandel's 'Mobbed' to Series|date=April 1, 2011|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=April 4, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U6LZYdp?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/fox-orders-howie-mandels-mobbed-173996|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} In April 2011, they started work on the film ''[[Make Your Move (film)|Make Your Move]]'' starring [[Derek Hough]] from ''Dancing With the Stars'' and [[K-pop]] singer [[BoA]] Kwon.{{cite web|title=BoA meets with hip hop choreographers Tabitha and Napoleon for "COBU 3D"|url=http://www.koreaboo.com/index.html/_/movies/boa-meets-with-hip-hop-choreographers-tabitha-a-r5535|work=KoreaBoo.com|date=April 15, 2011|accessdate=June 14, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U6WvRvx?url=http://www.koreaboo.com/index.html/_/movies/boa-meets-with-hip-hop-choreographers-tabitha-a-r5535|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite web|last=Sunhee|first=Han|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118031123|title=Hough, BoA partner in 'COBU 3D'|date=January 28, 2011|work=Variety|accessdate=June 14, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20130205000870|title=Korean-foreign productions create buzz for 2013|last=Lee|first=Claire|date=February 5, 2013|work=The Korea Herald|accessdate=April 10, 2013}} Their relationship with BoA extended past the production of the film when they choreographed the music video for her song "Only One"—the title track from her seventh studio album.{{cite web|author=A-Wei|title=Oriental Whirl: Hail the Queen|url=http://www.nst.com.my/life-times/tech/oriental-whirl-hail-the-queen-1.115361|work=[[New Straits Times]]|date=July 30, 2012|accessdate=August 12, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69r1SN5je?url=http://www.nst.com.my/life-times/tech/oriental-whirl-hail-the-queen-1.115361|archivedate=August 12, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} SeoulBeats.com called Tabitha and Napoleon's involvement "beyond perfect" and acknowledged that using lyrical hip-hop suited the song's tempo and BoA's movement.{{cite news|author=Gaya|title='Only One' Tale of Two BoA MVs|url=http://seoulbeats.com/2012/07/only-one-tale-of-two-boa-mvs|work=SeoulBeats.com|date=July 26, 2012|accessdate=September 5, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FhyfIIWg?url=http://seoulbeats.com/2012/07/only-one-tale-of-two-boa-mvs/|archivedate=April 7, 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}} Due to scheduling conflicts with the production of ''Make Your Move'', Tabitha and Napoleon did not return to ''America's Best Dance Crew'' as supervising choreographers for season six.{{cite web|last=Perry|first=Aliya|title=Full Access Interview with Tabitha and Napoleon|url=http://theindustryvoiceonline.com/uncategorized/full-access-interview-with-tabitha-napoleon.html|work=TheIndustryVoiceOnline.com|date=April 15, 2011|accessdate=June 14, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/634UZp3DF?url=http://theindustryvoiceonline.com/aliya-perry-author/full-access-interview-with-tabitha-napoleon.html|archivedate=November 9, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite web|last=Perry|first=Aliya|date=July 8, 2011|title=GET TO KNOW: Life After Winning ABDC. FULL ACCESS Interview with I Am Me. Creating Their Empire. Fame at 15 and MORE|url=http://theindustryvoiceonline.com/aliya-perry-author/get-to-know-life-after-winning-abdc-season-6-with-i-am-me-full-access-interview.html|work=TheIndustryVoiceOnline.com|accessdate=July 22, 2011|archivedate=November 9, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/634UFXQ0a?url=http://theindustryvoiceonline.com/aliya-perry-author/get-to-know-life-after-winning-abdc-season-6-with-i-am-me-full-access-interview.html|deadurl=yes|df=}} When filming was complete, they did return to Cirque du Soleil as two of ten choreographers for ''[[Michael Jackson: The Immortal World Tour]]''.{{cite web|title=Meet The Show's Creators|url=http://www.cirquedusoleil.com/en/shows/michael-jackson-tour/show/creators.aspx|work=CirqueDuSoleil.com|accessdate=September 4, 2011|archivedate=October 16, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U6pSv0D?url=http://www.cirquedusoleil.com/en/shows/michael-jackson-tour/show/creators.aspx|deadurl=yes|df=}} Like other stage shows they've worked on in the past, this one was directed by Jamie King.{{cite news|last=Pilato|first=Bruce|date=July 20, 2011|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118039762|title=Resurrecting Michael via Cirque Du Soleil|work=Variety|accessdate=November 22, 2011}} Christmas 2011 brought personal changes as Napoleon announced on their Twitter page that Tabitha was pregnant.{{cite web|last=Wolf|first=Stephanie|title=So You Think You Can Dance Choreographer Tabitha D'umo Is Pregnant!|url=http://www.wetpaint.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance/articles/so-you-think-you-can-dance-choreographer-tabitha-dumo-is-pregnant|work=WetPaint.com|accessdate=December 30, 2011|date=December 27, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65QoUHRst?url=http://www.wetpaint.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance/articles/so-you-think-you-can-dance-choreographer-tabitha-dumo-is-pregnant|archivedate=February 13, 2012|quote=Over the holiday, they announced on Twitter that they will be expecting a lil’ D’umo in the new year. Napoleon tweeted, 'What an amazing day. So many things to be thankful for. I remember Christmas' past... so many memories & so [many] presents! BUT this Christmas is the most memorable, and brings the best gift. I'm gonna be a DADDY. Tabitha is pregnant.'|deadurl=yes|df=}} ===2012–2016: Music videos, K-pop, and Las Vegas residencies=== Tabitha and Napoleon spent the beginning of 2012 apart. While Tabitha was choreographing [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s halftime performance for [[Super Bowl XLVI]],{{cite web|last=Wolf|first=Stephanie|title=Tabitha D'umo Choreographed Madonna's Super Bowl Halftime Routine|url=http://www.wetpaint.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance/articles/tabitha-dumo-choreographed-madonnas-super-bowl-halftime-routine|work=WetPaint.com|accessdate=February 12, 2012|date=February 6, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65Qo7iFCo?url=http://www.wetpaint.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance/articles/tabitha-dumo-choreographed-madonnas-super-bowl-halftime-routine|archivedate=February 13, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} Napoleon was shooting more scenes for ''Make Your Move'' and scouting for the [[America's Best Dance Crew (season 7)|seventh season]] of ''America's Best Dance Crew''.{{cite web|title=Season 4 audition advice from an ABDC audition judge: Who should try out?|url=http://bloggingbestdancecrew.blogspot.com/2009/05/season-4-audition-advice-from-abdc.html|work=BloggingBestDanceCrew.com|date=May 15, 2009|accessdate=October 17, 2012}} Although they never returned to ''America's Best Dance Crew'' as supervising choreographers, they did return in [[America's Best Dance Crew (season 8)|season eight]] as co-executive producers{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/music/nappytabs-name-their-all-time-favorite-americas-125221294356.html|title=Nappytabs Name Their All-Time Favorite 'America's Best Dance Crew' Routines|last=Parker|first=Lyndsey|date=July 29, 2015|work=Yahoo! Music|accessdate=September 19, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919104441/https://www.yahoo.com/music/nappytabs-name-their-all-time-favorite-americas-125221294356.html|archivedate=September 19, 2015}} After the Super Bowl, Tabitha worked with Madonna again. She choreographed her music video "[[Girl Gone Wild]]" which featured all-male Ukrainian dance troupe [[Kazaky]].{{cite web|title=Video Fashion Credits: Madonna "Girl Gone Wild"|date=March 26, 2012|url=http://musicfashionland.com/video-fashion-credits-madonna-girl-gone-wild|work=MusicFashionLand.com|accessdate=April 8, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66lxTYfqU?url=http://musicfashionland.com/video-fashion-credits-madonna-girl-gone-wild/|archivedate=April 8, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} During the last months of the year, Tabitha and Napoleon continued to work with K-pop artists. They choreographed the music videos "Humanoids" by [[TVXQ]] and "[[I Got a Boy (song)|I Got A Boy]]" by [[Girls' Generation]].{{cite web|title=오늘(1일) 오후 5시 소녀시대 'I Got a Boy' 드디어 풀공개|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20130101n06076|work=Nate.com|date=January 1, 2013|accessdate=January 1, 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DLrZ8yjQ?url=http://news.nate.com/view/20130101n06076|archivedate=January 1, 2013|language=ko|deadurl=yes|df=}} TVXQ, Girls' Generation, and BoA are all signed to [[S. M. Entertainment]]. [[Image:2009 BoA4.jpg|thumb|200px|right|K-pop singer BoA performing in 2009 at [[San Francisco Pride]].|alt=A young Korean female singing on stage wearing a sequined blue hoodie with blue and black tights.]] In April 2013, Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed the music video "Puttin' on the Ritz" by [[Herb Alpert]]. Two months later, they recreated the video on SYTYCD as the opening routine for [[So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. season 10)|season ten]]'s Top 20 performance episode. Yahoo! Music called the performance "absolutely epic".{{cite web|last=Parker|first=Lyndsey|date=June 25, 2013|title='SYTYCD' Puts on the Ritz for Season 10's First Live Episode|url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/reality-rocks/sytycd-puts-ritz-season-10-first-live-episode-020645015.html|work=Music.Yahoo.com|accessdate=July 5, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414031310/https://music.yahoo.com/blogs/reality-rocks/sytycd-puts-ritz-season-10-first-live-episode-020645015.html|archivedate=April 14, 2014}} Like the video, it was also shot in one take and several people made cameo appearances including [[Sean Cheesman]], [[Travis Wall]], [[Christopher Scott (choreographer)|Chris Scott]], [[Mary Murphy (choreographer)|Mary Murphy]], [[Jason Gilkison]], Nigel Lythgoe, Herb Alpert, Lani Hall, and Tabitha and Napoleon themselves.{{cite web|date=June 28, 2013|title=The Top 20 Put On The Ritz!|url=http://www.fox.com/dance/news/2013/June/top-20-perform|work=Fox.com|accessdate=July 5, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130707063358/http://www.fox.com/dance/news/2013/June/top-20-perform|archivedate=July 7, 2013}} In February 2014, Tabitha and Napoleon teamed up with TVXQ again to choreograph their music video "[[Spellbound (TVXQ album)#Lead single|Spellbound]]"—the title track from their seventh album. Just like Alpert's "Puttin' on the Ritz", this video was shot in one take, and just like BoA's "Only One", SeoulBeats.com gave it a positive review: "With two people in the group, there is not much of an opportunity to play around with different formations. However, Nappytabs tends to utilize this formation for TVXQ – rotating the members in the foreground and background, instead of always keeping the two in the centre. And this works especially well with the one-shot style, since it allows room for the duo to work the entire space on set, on and off-camera."{{cite web|author=Joyce|date=March 3, 2014|title=TVXQ Leaves Fans 'Spellbound'|url=http://seoulbeats.com/2014/03/tvxq-leaves-fans-spellbound|work=SeoulBeats.com|accessdate=April 19, 2014}} Billboard.com gave the video a positive review: "The duo makes a strong case for 2014's best choreography in the [Spellbound] video."{{cite web|last=Oak|first=Jessica|date=February 27, 2014|title=TVXQ! Enchants With New Single 'Spellbound'|work=Billboard.com|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/5922846/tvxq-enchants-with-new-single-spellbound|accessdate=April 19, 2014}} Tabitha and Napoleon also choreographed [[Super Junior-M]]'s music video "[[Swing (EP)|Swing]]"—the title track from their third [[Extended play|EP]].{{cite web|date=March 26, 2014|title=SUPER JUNIOR-M、新曲「SWING」でオフィスパフォーマンスを披露"NappyTabsの作品"|url=http://news.kstyle.com/article.ksn?articleNo=1991488|work=KStyle.com|quote=特に、「SWING」の振り付けは業務や日常などで溜まった疲労を見事に吹き飛ばそうとする歌詞の内容に合わせ、机や椅子などを活用したいわゆる“オフィスパフォーマンス”を披露し、ひとつのミュージカルを見るような華やかな構成のダンスで一気に視線を引きつける。|accessdate=April 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311005126/http://news.kstyle.com/article.ksn?articleNo=1991488|archivedate=March 11, 2016|language=ja}} They briefly returned to the stage as directors for sibling ballroom dancers [[Derek Hough|Derek]] and [[Julianne Hough]]'s ''Move Live on Tour''.{{cite news|last=Rizzo|first=Monica|date=March 18, 2014|title=Derek & Julianne Hough Will Soon Be Dancing in a City Near You|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20797902,00.html|work=People|accessdate=April 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222838/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20797902,00.html|archivedate=March 3, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Dallzel|first=Jenny|date=March 18, 2014|title=Derek Hough is Making Moves|url=http://www.dancespirit.com/2014/03/derek-hough-is-making-moves|work=Dance Spirit|accessdate=April 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108170333/http://www.dancespirit.com/2014/03/derek-hough-is-making-moves|archivedate=November 8, 2014}} After the ''Move'' tour, Tabitha and Napoleon continued to work on music videos. They choreographed [[Ed Sheeran]]'s music video for the single "[[Thinking Out Loud]]".{{cite news|date=October 8, 2014|url=http://www.dancespirit.com/2014/10/nappytabs-taught-ed-sheeran-dance|title=NappyTabs Taught Ed Sheeran to Dance|last=Fuhrer|first=Margaret|work=Dance Spirit|accessdate=November 8, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108152813/http://www.dancespirit.com/2014/10/nappytabs-taught-ed-sheeran-dance|archivedate=November 8, 2014}} Since its premiere, the video has amassed over 1.5 billion views.{{cite av media|date=October 7, 2014|title=Ed Sheeran - Thinking Out Loud [Official Video]|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lp-EO5I60KA|publisher=Asylum Records/Atlantic Records|medium=music video|accessdate=August 21, 2016}} They directed and choreographed the music video for "Harlem Hopscotch", the first single from [[Maya Angelou]]'s posthumous poetry album ''Caged Bird Songs''. The video premiered December 23, 2014, on Oprah.com and features cameo appearances by Derek Hough and actress [[Zendaya]].{{cite press release|title=Dr. Maya Angelou's "Harlem Hopscotch" Music Video Premiere Tuesday, December 23rd, 2014, on Oprah.com Directed by Emmy Winning Duo, Tabitha and Napolean Dumo and Produced by Smooch Music|publisher=Market Wired|date=December 23, 2014|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/dr-maya-angelous-harlem-hopscotch-music-video-premiere-tuesday-december-23rd-2014-on-1979320.htm|accessdate=December 31, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141231001017/http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/dr-maya-angelous-harlem-hopscotch-music-video-premiere-tuesday-december-23rd-2014-on-1979320.htm|archivedate=December 31, 2014}} The beginning of 2015 marked a return to K-pop.
