===2017–present: World of Dance=== Tabitha and Napoleon serve as co-executive producers and supervising choreographers for [[World of Dance (TV series)|World of Dance]] (WOD), a television show based off the [[World of Dance|hip-hop dance competition of the same name]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dancespirit.com/news/officer-another-dance-comp-tv-show-works|title=It’s Official: There’s Another Dance Comp TV Show in the Works|last=Munzenberger|first=Kelly|date=July 20, 2016|work=Dance Spirit|accessdate=December 30, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160806091819/http://www.dancespirit.com/news/officer-another-dance-comp-tv-show-works|archivedate=August 6, 2016}} This project will serve as a continuation of a long professional partnership they've had with Jennifer Lopez; her company Nuyorican Productions is developing the show.{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/2016/07/19/jennifer-lopez-nbc-world-of-dance-series/|title=Jennifer Lopez and NBC team up for World of Dance competition series|last=Lujan|first=Adam|date=July 19, 2016|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=December 30, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160720171634/http://www.ew.com/article/2016/07/19/jennifer-lopez-nbc-world-of-dance-series|archivedate=July 20, 2016}} Tabitha and Napoleon worked with Lopez in 2009 when they choreographed her performance at the ''[[American Music Awards]]''.{{cite news|last=Colbert|first=Quantrell|title=So You Think Jennifer Lopez Can Dance? She Can!|date=November 20, 2009|work=People|url=http://tvwatch.people.com/2009/11/20/so-you-think-jennifer-lopez-can-dance-she-can|accessdate=February 2, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwKa?url=http://tvwatch.people.com/2009/11/20/so-you-think-jennifer-lopez-can-dance-she-can/|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} They choreographed her 2011 music video "[[Papi (song)|Papi]]",{{cite web|url=http://www.wetpaint.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance/articles/tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo-choreograph-music-video-for-new-jennifer-lopez-single-papi|title=Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo Choreograph Music Video for New Jennifer Lopez Single Papi|last=Wolf|first=Stephanie|date=August 23, 2011|work=WetPaint.com|accessdate=January 22, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65QnqaMDJ?url=http://www.wetpaint.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance/articles/tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo-choreograph-music-video-for-new-jennifer-lopez-single-papi|archivedate=February 13, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} her 2014 ''[[A.K.A. (album)|A.K.A.]]'' promotional tour,{{cite web|url=http://www.msaagency.com/news/JloTour|work=MSAAgency.com|title=News Story|accessdate=June 8, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304031254/http://www.msaagency.com/news/JloTour|archivedate=March 4, 2016}} and her 2016 ''[[Jennifer Lopez: All I Have|All I Have]]'' residency at the Planet Hollywood Resort & Casino.{{cite web|last=Kennedy|first=Gerrick|date=January 24, 2016|title=Review Jennifer Lopez gives all she's got -- and more -- in Vegas|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-jennifer-lopez-vegas-20160124-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=May 25, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215083650/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-jennifer-lopez-vegas-20160124-story.html|archivedate=February 15, 2016}} Tabitha and Napoleon's relationship with WOD goes back to 2014 when they were judges at the competition's Los Angeles tour stop.{{cite web|title=Los Angeles World of Dance|url=http://www.worldofdance.com/events/los-angeles|work=WorldOfDance.com|accessdate=April 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150509102101/http://www.worldofdance.com/events/los-angeles|archivedate=May 9, 2015}} ==Choreography style== ===Artistry=== Tabitha and Napoleon's choreography is primarily hip-hop;{{cite web|url=http://idolator.com/5575431/five-minutes-with-tabitha-and-napoleon|title=Five Minutes With Tabitha And Napoleon Of ‘So You Think You Can Dance’|last=Adickman|first=Erika Brooks|date=July 28, 2010|work=Idolator.com|accessdate=January 22, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64tBjeHdJ?url=http://idolator.com/5575431/five-minutes-with-tabitha-and-napoleon|archivedate=January 22, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} however, it varies across genres depending on what project they're working on. For example, on ''America's Best Dance Crew'' all of the group routines they choreographed were hip-hop. However, on ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (SYTYCD) they choreographed a few jazz routines and on Cirque du Soleil their work incorporated [[Acro dance|acro]].{{cite av media|people=Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo |date=February 26, 2010|title=Napoleon and Tabitha D'umo at World Premiere of Viva Elvis|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y8aT6Y_EiUQm|type=Interview|publisher=MyVegasNet|location=Las Vegas, NV|accessdate=August 1, 2010|time=:35}} In general, their choreography emphasizes big visuals, which they attribute to their cheerleading past, and is "...largely centered on storytelling and physical comedy." Inspiration for lifts is taken from [[lucha libre]], [[Adagio (acrobatics)|adagio]], and [[Swing (dance)|swing dance]]. The style they are most known for is lyrical hip-hop. ===Lyrical hip-hop=== Lyrical dance is a studio-based dance style that uses a combination of classical dance techniques from jazz and ballet to tell a story through movement.{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Gray|title=Lyrical Dancing|url=http://dance.lovetoknow.com/Lyrical_Dancing|work=LoveToKnow.com|accessdate=November 1, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62rlY7Lbd?url=http://dance.lovetoknow.com/Lyrical_Dancing|archivedate=November 1, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} With jazz and ballet, technique alone can provide a good performance but in lyrical dance expressing emotion is emphasized just as much as technique. [[Hip-hop dance|Hip-hop]] is an urban dance style that is characterized as hard-hitting involving isolations{{cite journal|last=Wisner|first=Heather|date=October 2007|title=Crash Course: Hip Hop|journal=Dance|volume=81|issue=10|pages=82–85|issn=0011-6009}}—moving certain body parts independently from others—and musicality,{{cite journal|last=Levinson|first=Lauren|date=July 2010|title=Finding Your Groove|journal=Dance Spirit|volume=14|issue=6|page=76|issn=1094-0588}} the body's sensitivity to changes in music. Hip-hop can incorporate movement from its substyles [[locking (dance)|locking]], breaking, [[popping]], and [[The Electric Boogaloos|boogaloo]] to add a different movement quality but conveying emotion does not have to be present as the dance is more about bravado and personal enjoyment. Lyrical hip-hop is a fluid and more interpretive version of standard hip-hop. It combines the nuances of lyrical dance with the vocabulary and foundational movements found in hip-hop. According to ''Dance Spirit'' magazine, what differentiates lyrical hip-hop from standard hip-hop is that dancers interpret the beat differently.{{cite journal|last=Levinson|first=Lauren|date=May 1, 2009|title=Lyrical Hip Hop|journal=Dance Spirit|volume=13|issue=5|pages=48–50|url=http://www.dancespirit.com/2011/01/lyrical_hip_hop|accessdate=April 25, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdcI?url=http://www.dancespirit.com/articles/2131|archivedate=May 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} In lyrical hip-hop there are still isolations, gliding, and body waves just like in standard hip-hop. However, the movements are smoother and more fluid rather than hard-hitting and, like lyrical dance, emphasis is placed on storytelling and conveying emotion through the choreography. {{quote box|align=right|width=220px|bgcolor=#ADD8E6|quote="This is one of the great things about this show is that we've really explored a totally new thing which is lyrical hip-hop and [Tabitha and Napoleon] nail it... It shows you that hip-hop [has] completely become a really legitimate beautiful genre in and of its own and you can tell such beautiful and heart breaking stories."|source=Adam Shankman{{cite episode|title=The Top 16 Perform|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (United States)|network=[[Fox TV|Fox]]|airdate=June 25, 2008|season=4|number=10}}}} Lyrical hip-hop first gained mainstream exposure, and its name, in 2008 on season four of SYTYCD. The term itself is credited to [[Adam Shankman]], a choreographer and judge on the program, who made a comment in reference to a routine choreographed by Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo to Leona Lewis' song "[[Bleeding Love]]". Due to Shankman's comment and their subsequent work on seasons four through seven, Tabitha and Napoleon are credited with developing this style.{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Jesse|title=Lyrical Hip Hop Takes Center Stage|work=The Expressionist|date=June 25, 2008|url=http://www.theexpressionist.com/2008/06/25/lyrical-hip-hop-takes-center-stage|accessdate=April 12, 2008|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qsjEfwKT?url=http://www.theexpressionist.com/2008/06/25/lyrical-hip-hop-takes-center-stage/|archivedate=June 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Some hip-hop purists feel the interpretive and softer approach means lyrical hip-hop is not hip-hop at all. From a purist perspective, dancing to the lyrics would make the choreography [[wikt:linear|linear]] and too technical. This is because dancing to the words would take precedence over dancing to the beat. Traditionally in hip-hop, dancing to the beat is essential; lyrics can accent the movement, but the beat is the guiding force for the dancing.{{cite web|title=Physical Graffiti... The History of Hip Hop Dance|last=Pabon|first=Jorge|url=http://www.daveyd.com/historyphysicalgrafittifabel.html|work=DaveyD.com|accessdate=July 31, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdUk?url=http://www.daveyd.com/historyphysicalgrafittifabel.html|archivedate=May 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Other hip-hop dancers, such as choreographer [[Shane Sparks]], believe that lyrical hip-hop is hip-hop but not different enough for it to have a separate label or be in its own subgenre. ===Teaching=== Although Tabitha and Napoleon have a solid career in choreography and creative direction, they spend a significant amount of time teaching classes at dance studios and conventions. They have stated that teaching helps their choreography because it keeps them current on new hip-hop social dances (party dances). They are faculty members at Monsters of Hip Hop dance convention. In the past they have taught at Shock the Intensive, the Edge Performing Arts Center, Millennium Dance Complex, Hip Hop International, Dance Blitz, Seattle Theater Group, Coastal Dance Rage, the Dance Teacher Web Conference and Expo, Teen Dance Company of the Bay Area, JUMP, Xtreme Dance Force, ProDance, Triple Threat Dance, Project 818, Boogiezone, iHollywood, the So You Think You Can Dance Experience, DANCE! Is coming to Atlantic City Feb 2nd!|url=http://www.unitedstatestournamentofdance.com/nappytabs-dance-is-coming-to-atlantic-city-feb-2nd|work=UnitedStatesTournamentofDance.com|accessdate=February 7, 2013|date=January 4, 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EFj85YYI?url=http://www.unitedstatestournamentofdance.com/nappytabs-dance-is-coming-to-atlantic-city-feb-2nd/|archivedate=February 7, 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}} *For Velocity Dance Convention, see: {{cite web|title=Faculty|url=http://velocitydanceconvention.com/main/faculty|work=VelocityDanceConvention.com|accessdate=November 30, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203005438/http://velocitydanceconvention.com/main/faculty|archivedate=December 3, 2013}} *For Radix, see: {{cite web|title=Faculty|url=http://www.radixdance.com/faculty/tabithanapoleondumo|work=RadixDance.com|accessdate=September 19, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919115435/http://www.radixdance.com/faculty/tabithanapoleondumo|archivedate=September 19, 2015}} *For The Zoo, see: {{cite web|title=Faculty|url=http://www.nappytabszoo.com/faculty|work=nappytabszoo.com|accessdate=November 8, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151108120046/http://www.nappytabszoo.com/faculty|archivedate=November 8, 2015}} *For VIP Dance Events, see: {{cite web|title=WHO: Choreographers|url=http://vipdanceevents.com/about-us|work=VIPDanceEvents.com|accessdate=April 19, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304093341/http://vipdanceevents.com/about-us|archivedate=March 4, 2014}} ==Critical reception== ===JabbaWockeeZ=== The [[JabbaWockeeZ]] performed the show ''MÜS.I.C.'' from May 2010 to September 2012. Over the course of their two-year run, the show received mixed reviews. For their second show ''PRiSM'' they signed a six-year deal which included building a new 830-seat theater in a space that used to house a motion-simulator ride. Upon opening, ''PRiSM'' was met with positive reviews. Tabitha and Napoleon directed both shows. ====''MÜS.I.C.''==== [[Image:JabbaWockeeZ in San Jose.jpg|thumb|right|The JabbaWockeeZ performing in 2008 at Vivid Nightclub in [[San Jose, CA]].|alt=A close-up shot of a performance by four young men in a hip-hop dance crew dressed in black slacks, white t-shirts, white face masks, and red baseball caps.]] The first run of ''MÜS.I.C.'' was held at the MGM Grand Las Vegas hotel and casino. ''Las Vegas Weekly'' wrote that ''MÜS.I.C.'' had "game-changing potential" because it was the first time [[hip-hop dance]] had headlined a show on the Las Vegas Strip.{{cite web |last=Corbin |first=April |url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2010/may/09/awesome-anonymity/ |title=Awesome anonymity |work=Las Vegas Weekly |date=May 9, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPNh?url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2010/may/09/awesome-anonymity/ |archivedate=August 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In contrast, the ''Las Vegas Review-Journal'' (LVRJ) criticized the show for being repetitious and for having a bare stage for the first 20 minutes.{{cite news|last=Weatherford|first=Mike|url=http://www.lvrj.com/neon/jabbawockeez-93757434.html|title=SHOW REVIEW: Jabbawockeez|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 14, 2010|accessdate=August 1, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U8Sd1Ej?url=http://www.lvrj.com/neon/jabbawockeez-93757434.html|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} LVRJ also criticized the use of masks as not appealing to a casual viewer because it inhibited the dancers' personality: "Even if a generational split is in play here, it would be tough to hear the creators argue that the show would suffer if, after 20 minutes or so -- gasp! -- makeup or clown-face replaced the masks to expand the original concept." In October 2010, the show moved to the Monte Carlo Resort and Casino. Changes to the original show included a bigger stage, a new set, and added dance routines.{{cite news|last=Colton|first=Sandra|title=NappyTabs Preview The Jabbawockeez 'MUS.I.C' at The Monte Carlo|url=http://www.dancetrackmagazine.com/?p=2213|work=Dance Track|date=October 6, 2010|accessdate=October 18, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U8hNki7?url=http://www.dancetrackmagazine.com/?p=2213|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} CraveOnline.com called the new show "amazing"{{cite web|last=Childress|first=Ahmad|date=October 23, 2010|title=Jabbawockeez MUS.I.C opens at the Monte Carlo|url=http://www.craveonline.com/lifestyle/article/jabbawockeez-music-opens-at-the-monte-carlo-115007|work=CraveOnline.com|accessdate=November 30, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uckrLi7a?url=http://www.craveonline.com/lifestyle/article/jabbawockeez-music-opens-at-the-monte-carlo-115007|archivedate=November 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} and Zap2It.com described it as "a vibrant, frenetic and multi-genre extravaganza of visuals, sound and movement."{{cite web|last=Nguyen|first=Hanh|date=October 31, 2010|title=JabbaWockeez MUS.I.C. at the Monte Carlo Las Vegas: A behind-the-mask expose|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2010/10/jabbawockeez-music-at-the-monte-carlo-las-vegas-a-behind-the-mask-expose.html|work=Zap2It.com|accessdate=November 30, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uciBECLu?url=http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2010/10/jabbawockeez-music-at-the-monte-carlo-las-vegas-a-behind-the-mask-expose.html|archivedate=November 30, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} In April 2012, the Jabbawockeez began running two ''MÜS.I.C.'' shows in tandem. Some members stayed with the flagship show in Las Vegas while the others took the show on limited residencies elsewhere. Their first residency outside Las Vegas was in Australia at the Jupiters Hotel and Casino in [[Gold Coast, Queensland]].{{cite news|last=Browne|first=Sally|title=US dance sensation Jabbawokeez to land at Jupiters|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/life/whatson/us-dance-sensation-to-land-on-jupiters/story-fn8zvh1s-1226326724554|accessdate=May 22, 2012|newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]]|date=June 15, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67qUE6JVT?url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/life/whatson/us-dance-sensation-to-land-on-jupiters/story-fn8zvh1s-1226326724554|archivedate=May 22, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} ''Gold Coast Magazine'' gave the show a good review describing it as "magical... it truly does stir an emotional response through your soul and the combination of dance and drama make it appealing to all ages."{{cite news|author=Kirra|title=REVIEW: Jabbawockeez MÜS.I.C.|url=http://www.goldcoastmagazine.com.au/2012/04/review-jabbawockeez-mus-i-c|work=Gold Coast Magazine|date=April 25, 2012|accessdate=June 19, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68XsjlKMU?url=http://www.goldcoastmagazine.com.au/2012/04/review-jabbawockeez-mus-i-c/|archivedate=June 19, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} After leaving Jupiters, the Jabbawockeez took up a second month-long residency in August 2012 at Harrah's Resort Atlantic City casino in New Jersey. Philly.com gave it a lukewarm review: "The problem is that as good as Jabbawockeez is at what [they do], the novelty wears off about a third-way through the show... the bulk of the performance pretty much offers little more than variations on a theme. As such, Jabbawockeez would have much more impact as a featured act in a variety show than it has on its own."{{cite news|last=Darrow|first=Chuck|date=August 17, 2012|title=Casinos offer booze you can use|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/casinotes/166521402.html|work=Philly.com|accessdate=August 28, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AFCd9gBF?url=http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/casinotes/166521402.html|archivedate=August 28, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} The members that stayed in Las Vegas temporarily moved into an 800-seat tent outside the Monte Carlo to continue their show. VegasChatter.com reviewed the tent show and called it "an entertaining, fun, and interactive performance show."{{cite web|date=June 29, 2012|title=Jabbawockeez: Entertainment Without A Face (Or Words)|url=http://www.vegaschatter.com/story/2012/6/28/225554/278/vegas-travel/Jabbawockeez%3A+Entertainment+Without+A+Face+%28Or+Words%29|work=VegasChatter.com|accessdate=May 28, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715044148/http://www.vegaschatter.com/story/2012/6/28/225554/278/vegas-travel/Jabbawockeez%3A+Entertainment+Without+A+Face+%28Or+Words%29|archivedate=July 15, 2014}} They performed in the tent from June 2012 through September 2012 with the understanding they would take up residence in the Luxor Las Vegas hotel and casino in the Spring of 2013.{{cite web|date=April 23, 2012|title=Jabbawockeez To Pop And Lock Again Soon|url=http://www.vegaschatter.com/story/2012/4/23/123556/526/vegas-travel/Jabbawockeez+To+Pop+And+Lock+Again+Soon|work=VegasChatter.com|accessdate=May 28, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120630044336/http://www.vegaschatter.com/story/2012/4/23/123556/526/vegas-travel/Jabbawockeez+To+Pop+And+Lock+Again+Soon|archivedate=June 30, 2012}} ====''PRiSM''==== The JabbaWockeeZ second stage show ''PRiSM'' opened at the Luxor Las Vegas on May 31, 2013. The show's original title was ''Nonsense'' (a nod to [[Jabberwocky|the crew's name]]) because, at the time, they lacked a cohesive theme. However, it was Napoleon's idea to change the title to ''PRiSM'' since there are seven crew members and when light goes into a [[Dispersive prism|prism]], seven colors emerge (the Luxor hotel is in the shape of a triangular prism). From that point on, unity and color became the themes of the show{{cite web|last=Weatherford|first=Mike|date=May 16, 2013|title=Jabbawockeez showing another side in new show 'Prism'|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/shows/jabbawockeez-showing-another-side-new-show-prism|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=May 30, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616172215/http://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/shows/jabbawockeez-showing-another-side-new-show-prism|archivedate=June 16, 2013}} and the title was given the [[backronym]] Painting Reality in a Spectrum of Movement.{{cite web|last=Lane|first=Richard|date=May 17, 2013|title=Look Inside The World Of Jabbawockeez's PRiSM|url=http://www.vegaschatter.com/story/2013/5/17/17222/8593/vegas-travel/Look+Inside+The+World+Of+Jabbawockeez's+PRiSM|work=VegasChatter.com|accessdate=May 30, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622124632/http://www.vegaschatter.com/story/2013/5/17/17222/8593/vegas-travel/Look+Inside+The+World+Of+Jabbawockeez's+PRiSM|archivedate=June 22, 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}} ''PRiSM'' received positive reviews. ''Las Vegas Weekly'' wrote "Those who deride the art of pantomime or breakdancing need to check this show out. It will change your mind."{{cite news|last=Katsilometes|first=Josh|date=June 5, 2013 |title=Ever-evolving Jabbawockeez make a point at Luxor|url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/blogs/kats-report/2013/jun/05/ever-evolving-jabbawockeez-make-point-luxor|work=Las Vegas Weekly|accessdate=June 9, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419184105/http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/blogs/kats-report/2013/jun/05/ever-evolving-jabbawockeez-make-point-luxor/#/0|archivedate=April 19, 2014}} ''Las Vegas Sun'' (LVS) described the show as "a mix of great choreography, interesting storylines and special effects reminiscent of [[Electric Daisy Carnival]]...". LVS wrote "It’s great to see a different kind of headliner — in content and ethnic makeup — thriving on the Strip."{{cite news|last=Chareunsy|first=Don|date=June 5, 2013|title=Photos: Jabbawockeez shine bright, more intimate in ‘Prism’ at Luxor|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/jun/05/photos-jabbawockeez-shine-bright-more-intimate-pr|work=Las Vegas Sun|accessdate=June 9, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712080142/http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/jun/05/photos-jabbawockeez-shine-bright-more-intimate-pr/#axzz2VkEfxX1m|archivedate=July 12, 2013}} ''Vegas Kool'' stated that the new theater "...is laid out [so] everyone has a great view of the stage."{{cite web|last=Ginsberg|first=Gabe|date=June 13, 2013|title=Las Vegas’ newest show to hit the Strip Jabbawockeez PRiSM|url=http://vegaskool.com/2013/06/13/jabbawockeez|work=Vegas Kool|accessdate=June 19, 2013}} ''Las Vegas Review-Journal'' (LVRJ) directly addressed Tabitha and Napoleon's involvement in "...turning the Jabbawockeez brand into an oddly endearing mix of mime, modern dance and physical theater."{{cite news|last=Weatherford|first=Mike|date=June 6, 2013 |title=Jabbawockeez release positive energy in 'Prism'|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/entertainment/shows/jabbawockeez-release-positive-energy-prism|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=June 9, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611211838/http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/entertainment/shows/jabbawockeez-release-positive-energy-prism|archivedate=June 11, 2013}} Several reviewers noted that overall ''PRiSM'' is better than ''MÜS.I.C.'' LVRJ wrote "...it all seems to hang together better this time, with a seamless flow and unifying themes of brotherhood and diversity." ''Dance Track Magazine'' wrote "Not only does the show have a much more intimate feel than previous Jabbawockeez shows, but ''PRiSM'' also includes increased audience participation, intensified humor and a storyline that is dramatic and flows through the entire performance."{{cite news|last=Colton|first=Sandra|title=Jabbawockeez Blaze New Vision in PRiSM|url=http://www.dancetrackmagazine.com/jabbawockeez-see-new-vision-in-prism|date=May 25, 2013|work=Dance Track Magazine|accessdate=June 19, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609071849/http://www.dancetrackmagazine.com/jabbawockeez-see-new-vision-in-prism/|archivedate=June 9, 2013}} IGoShows.com had the same observation: "...the [previous] shows were plagued by lost opportunities, undeveloped ideas, and repetition. They seem to have corrected these shortcomings. 'Prism' is better in almost every way over its predecessors. The show has a cohesiveness that it never had before, good follow-through on ideas, and far more intriguing staging. The choreography is strong, varied, and doesn’t suffer the repetition that had invaded it previously."{{cite web|last=Rounds|first=Chuck|title=Jabbawockeez - Prism|url=http://www.igoshows.com/reviews/review234.html|work=IGoShows.com|date=June 6, 2013|accessdate=July 21, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130408034628/http://www.igoshows.com/reviews/review234.html|archivedate=April 8, 2013}} ===''So You Think You Can Dance''=== Most criticism of Tabitha and Napoleon's choreography has come as a result of their work on ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (SYTYCD). Over the course of their involvement with the show, they have received mixed reviews. At worst, their choreography has been criticized as "softie hip-hop (more like 'hip-pop')".{{cite web|last=Parker|first=Lyndsey|title=‘SYTYCD’ Top 8 Recap: All Aboard The Hot Jalapeño Bus!|url=http://ca.music.yahoo.com/blogs/reality-rocks/sytycd-top-8-recap-aboard-hot-jalape%C3%B1o-bus-052735747.html|work=Music.Yahoo.com|date=August 30, 2012|accessdate=September 5, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ASjYtrwb?url=http://ca.music.yahoo.com/blogs/reality-rocks/sytycd-top-8-recap-aboard-hot-jalape%C3%B1o-bus-052735747.html|archivedate=September 5, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} At best, it has been described as "amazing" and "bring[ing] out the best in their dancers..."{{cite web|last=Wolf|first=Stephanie|title=The Top 5 Best NappyTabs Routines of All Time (VIDEOS)|url=http://www.wetpaint.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance/articles/the-top-5-best-nappytabs-routines-of-all-time-videos-|work=WetPaint.com|date=February 21, 2012|accessdate=September 5, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ASjQYNcd?url=http://www.wetpaint.com/so-you-think-you-can-dance/articles/the-top-5-best-nappytabs-routines-of-all-time-videos-|archivedate=September 5, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} ====Seasons four, five, and six==== {{quote box|align=right|width=220px|bgcolor=#ADD8E6|quote="[Katee and Joshua] did a routine to my song, 'No Air,' and it was crazy to see how they moved to it. It was beautiful and I totally saw the story. I got chills... I played it 100 times."|source=Jordin Sparks{{cite news|last=Corneau |first=Allison|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/sytycd-jordin-sparks-talks-to-us|title=Jordin Sparks: I Got Chills When I Saw Katee and Joshua Dance to My Song|work=[[Us Weekly|Us Magazine]]|date=July 1, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116002622/http://www.usmagazine.com/sytycd-jordin-sparks-talks-to-us|archivedate=January 16, 2009|accessdate=July 4, 2010}}}} Lyrical hip-hop gained exposure and popularity during Tabitha and Napoleon's first season with SYTYCD (season four). On the first performance episode, contestants Katee Shean and Joshua Allen performed a D'umo choreographed lyrical hip-hop piece to the song "[[No Air]]" by [[Jordin Sparks]]. This routine received positive reviews and was later chosen as a "Judges' Favorite" by judge and executive producer [[Nigel Lythgoe]] to be performed again during the finale.{{cite web|last=Chang|first=Debbie|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/so-you-think-you-can-dance/so-you-think-you-can-dance-4-s-21859.aspx|title=So You Think You Can Dance 4: Season Finale Live Thoughts|date=August 7, 2008|work=BuddyTV.com|accessdate=July 8, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPO9?url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/so-you-think-you-can-dance/so-you-think-you-can-dance-4-s-21859.aspx|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} BuddyTV.com wrote that the routine deserved an Emmy nomination.{{cite web|last=Simmons|first=Abbey|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/so-you-think-you-can-dance/so-you-think-you-can-dance-sco-30058.aspx|title=So You Think You Can Dance Scores Five Emmy Nominations|work=BuddyTV.com|date=July 16, 2009|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPOI?url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/so-you-think-you-can-dance/so-you-think-you-can-dance-sco-30058.aspx|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Although Tabitha and Napoleon were not nominated for "No Air", they were nominated for "Bleeding Love", another lyrical hip-hop routine performed by [[Mark Kanemura]] and [[Chelsie Hightower]] which the ''San Francisco Gate'' called a "great drama from hip-hop choreographers Tabitha and Napoleon D'Umo, danced with chemistry and theatrical flair."{{cite news|last=Howard|first=Rachel|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2008-09-27/entertainment/17160150_1_hip-hop-dance-katee-shean|title=Dance review: 'Dance' fever in San Jose|work=San Francisco Gate|date=September 27, 2008|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPOR?url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2008-09-27/entertainment/17160150_1_hip-hop-dance-katee-shean|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} This routine was picked as a "Judges' Favorite" by choreographer and judge Christopher "[[Lil' C]]" Toler. In June 2010, TVSquad.com named "No Air" and "Bleeding Love" two of the ten best routines from all seasons of SYTYCD.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2010/06/23/best-so-you-think-you-can-dance-performances|title=Best 'So You Think You Can Dance' Performances: Does Alex Wong Belong?|date=June 23, 2010|last=Hughes|first=Jason|work=TVSquad.com|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPOa?url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2010/06/23/best-so-you-think-you-can-dance-performances/|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} A third Tabitha and Napoleon lyrical hip-hop routine choreographed to [[Alicia Keys]]' song "[[Like You'll Never See Me Again]]" did not receive as much critical praise or attention as "Bleeding Love" or "No Air"; however, Nigel Lythgoe confessed when giving feedback on the dance that season four was the first time he had been emotionally affected by hip-hop routines.{{cite episode|title=Top 8 Perform|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (season 4)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=July 23, 2008|season=4|number=18|quote=Tabitha and Napoleon have done some incredible stuff this season and this is another one for me. I guess it's the first season... where I've been affected emotionally by hip-hop routines. Normally I expect it from contemporary routines but this season I guess 'No Air' did, 'Bleeding Love' did and this one—and I love Alicia Keys, I mean the whole thing you know reminded me of ''[[Ghost (1990 film)|Ghost]]''}}. Seasons five and six brought less praise for Tabitha and Napoleon. During season five's Top 8 performance episode, Lythgoe commented after a hip-hop routine choreographed by [[Shane Sparks]] "It's wonderful to have Shane Sparks back this season. He brings something else... I've been a little disappointed with our hip-hop this year."{{cite episode|title=Top 8 Perform|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (season 5)|credits=Nigel Lythgoe (executive producer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=July 22, 2009|season=5|number=18}} Out of the ten hip-hop routines (both couples and group routines) choreographed on season five previous to Lythgoe's comment, Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed seven. The most significant criticism came during season six in response to "[[People Are Strange|People are Strange]]"—a routine about how [[Extraterrestrial life|aliens]] would attempt to dance hip-hop. None of the judges liked the routine. Lythgoe said the routine placed concept (theme) over substance (dancing).{{cite episode|title=Top 8 Perform|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (season 6)|credits=Nigel Lythogoe (executive producer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=December 8, 2009|season=6|number=23}} All the judges felt that the dance was weird and that the choreography was more to blame for the dancers' performance than the dancing itself. Of the routine "[[Give It to Me Right|Give it to me Right]]" that Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed on a later season six episode about two fraternizing office employees, TVSquad.com wrote that many parts were awkward and that the dance only became enjoyable once the dancers "stopped cavorting around the desk and got out on the floor."{{cite web|last=Hughes|first=Jason|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/12/02/review-so-you-think-you-can-dance-top-10-perform-recap|title=Review: So You Think You Can Dance - Top 10 Perform|work=TVSquad.com|date=December 2, 2009|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPOj?url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2009/12/02/review-so-you-think-you-can-dance-top-10-perform-recap/|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} In contrast to the mediocre to bad reviews, two other routines they choreographed were picked as "Judges' Favorite" during the season six finale: "[[Beggin'#Madcon version|Beggin']]" (chosen by Lil' C) and "[[I Can Transform Ya]]" (chosen by Mary Murphy).{{cite episode|title=Winner Announced|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (season 6)|credits=Nigel Lythogoe (executive producer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=December 16, 2009|season=6|number=29}} ====Seasons seven and eight==== Tabitha and Napoleon received their best reviews on SYTYCD during season seven after a performance they choreographed to the song "[[Crunk Rock|Outta Your Mind]]" by [[Lil Jon]]. Creators.com called the routine "brilliantly imaginative."{{cite web|url=http://www.creators.com/lifestylefeatures/fashion-and-entertainment/hollywood-exclusive/-twitch-doing-fast-footwork-between-sytycd-and-step-up-3d.html|title='Twitch' Doing Fast Footwork Between 'SYTYCD' and 'Step Up 3D'|work=Creators.com|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPPS?url=http://www.creators.com/lifestylefeatures/fashion-and-entertainment/hollywood-exclusive/-twitch-doing-fast-footwork-between-sytycd-and-step-up-3d.html|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} ''Pioneer Local'' called it "powerful... It's been so long since [Tabitha and Napoleon] have had a showstopping hip-hop number on SYTYCD. Not since Season 4 when they had Katee, Joshua, tWitch, Mark and Chelsie have they pulled out hip-hop this good."{{cite web|last=Thomas|first=Jennifer|url=http://blogs.pioneerlocal.com/entertainment/2010/07/so_you_think_you_can_dance_top_14.html|title=So You Think You Can Dance Top 9: Still twitchin' over Alex's hip-hop|date=July 1, 2010|work=Pioneer Local|accessdate=July 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704040813/http://blogs.pioneerlocal.com/entertainment/2010/07/so_you_think_you_can_dance_top_14.html|archivedate=July 4, 2010|df=}} The routine was performed by ballet dancer Alex Wong and "All-Star" hip-hop dancer Stephen "tWitch" Boss from season four. The concept is about a psychologist (tWitch) who teaches a dancer (Alex) to let go of his technique and inhibitions and just dance. After the performance, tWitch and Alex received a standing ovation from the crowd and all three judges—Nigel Lythgoe, Mia Michaels, and Adam Shankman. Host [[Cat Deeley]] commented "I have never, never, in 'So You Think You Can Dance' history, heard a roar from a crowd like this - ever."{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Joyce|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-31749_162-20009393-10391698.html|title=Christina Perri's Song Featured on 'So You Think You Can Dance;' Alex Wong Remains on Top|work=CBSNews.com|date=July 1, 2010|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPP1?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-31749_162-20009393-10391698.html|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} Lythgoe called the concept "brilliant... This is about a ballet dancer doing the most incredible hip-hop... If this routine and you are not up for an Emmy with Napoleon and Tabitha next year, I don't know why not. It's probably one of the funnest, best hip-hop routines we've ever had on this show."{{cite web|last=Rocchio|first=Christopher|date=July 1, 2010|url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/so-you-think-you-can-dance-top-9-finalists-take-stage-11286.php|title='So You Think You Can Dance's Top 9 finalists take to the stage|work=RealityTVWorld.com|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPPA?url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/so-you-think-you-can-dance-top-9-finalists-take-stage-11286.php|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} In slight disagreement, the ''Wall Street Journal'' noted that "Outta Your Mind" may in fact be nominated for an Emmy, but it is unlikely to win because past winners have all been lyrical, very emotional routines.{{cite news|last=Watson|first=Tracy|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/07/01/can-twilex-win-an-emmy-for-their-so-you-think-you-can-dance-routine|date=July 1, 2010|title=Can Twilex Win an Emmy for Their ‘So You Think You Can Dance’ Routine?|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPPJ?url=http://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/07/01/can-twilex-win-an-emmy-for-their-so-you-think-you-can-dance-routine/|archivedate=August 28, 2010|work=The Wall Street Journal|deadurl=yes|df=}} [[Image:EllenTwitchSYTYCD.png|thumb|left|300px|A screenshot from the ''So You Think You Can Dance'' season seven finale showing [[Ellen DeGeneres]] and hip-hop dancer tWitch performing "Outta Your Mind".|alt=A screenshot showing an older Caucasian woman with her dance partner, a tall African-American male, on a shinny gray stage at the end of their hip-hop performance.]] On a later episode, Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed a lyrical hip-hop routine to [[Alicia Keys]] debut single "[[Fallin' (Alicia Keys song)|Fallin']]". Of the dance, judge Mia Michaels stated "That to me felt more real than any [[contemporary dance|contemporary]] piece, honestly, because it came from such a raw raw space and place. That was absolutely unbelievable, and it was like watching a dance film."{{cite episode |title=Top 6 Perform|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (season 7)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Corporation|FOX]]|airdate=July 21, 2010|season=7|number=20}} Lythgoe stated that the dance reminded him of "Bleeding Love" and "No Air" from season four and added "Somehow Napoleon and Tabitha have this ability... to put emotion into hip-hop routines and it really is a real talent." The positive reviews continued through the rest of the season. Of Tabitha and Napoleon's "[[Scars (Basement Jaxx album)|Scars]]" routine about angry clowns, Lythgoe called the piece "stunning" and Michaels described it as "hip-hop theater".{{cite episode|title=Top 4 Perform|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. TV series)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=August 4, 2010|season=7|number=24}} After the episode aired, ''Dance Spirit'' magazine wrote "Tabitha and Napoleon are on FIRE this season!"{{cite web|last=Fuhrer|first=Margaret|title="SYTYCD" Season 7: Top 4 Performances|url=http://www.dancespirit.com/2010/08/SYTYCD_Season_7_Top_4_Performances|work=Dance Spirit|accessdate=February 12, 2012|date=August 5, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65Qp6sj0g?url=http://www.dancespirit.com/2010/08/SYTYCD_Season_7_Top_4_Performances/|archivedate=February 13, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} The ''Los Angeles Times'' echoed this comment stating that season seven had been "Nappytabs' best season".{{cite news|last=Zulkey|first=Claire|title='So You Think You Can Dance': Tears of a creepy clown|date=August 4, 2010|work=Los Angeles Times|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2010/08/so-you-think-you-can-dance-tears-of-a-creepy-clown.html|accessdate=August 15, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPPt?url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2010/08/so-you-think-you-can-dance-tears-of-a-creepy-clown.html|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} On the Top 3 performance episode, after their "[[Power (Kanye West song)|Power]]" routine danced by eventual champion Lauren Froderman and "All-Star" tWitch, Michaels commented "Nappytabs what a season you have had, my God. It's been like home run after home run after home run..."{{cite episode|title=Top 3 Perform|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. TV series)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=August 11, 2010|season=7|number=26}} Shankman echoed this comment on the finale by calling Tabitha and Napoleon "the [[Most Valuable Player|MVP]]s of the season".{{cite episode|title=Winner Announced|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. TV series)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=August 12, 2010|minutes=1:00:35|season=7|number=27}} Four of their routines—"Fallin'", "Scars", "Battle for the Beat", and "[[My Chick Bad]]"—were chosen as "Judges' Favorite" during the season seven finale broadcast.{{cite episode|title=Winner Announced|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. TV series)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=August 12, 2010|season=7|number=27}} Due to an injury sustained by Alex Wong, "Outta Your Mind" was not picked as a judge's favorite. Instead, it was performed by tWitch and special guest [[Ellen DeGeneres]] as a tribute to Alex just before Lauren Froderman was declared the winner of season seven. Season eight brought back mixed feedback. Early in the season, Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed a lyrical hip-hop routine "[[Coming Home (Diddy-Dirty Money song)|Coming Home]]" about a veteran coming back to his wife after returning from his [[wikt:deployment|deployment]]. The routine generated positive while emotional responses causing both guest judge [[Debbie Reynolds]] and resident judge Mary Murphy to cry while giving feedback.{{cite web|last=Hughes|first=Jason|title=Sasha and Alexander Move Judges to Tears on 'So You Think You Can Dance'|url=http://www.aoltv.com/2011/06/23/sasha-alexander-move-judges-to-tears-sytycd-video|work=AOLTV.com|date=June 23, 2011|accessdate=August 6, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U95i1tg?url=http://www.aoltv.com/2011/06/23/sasha-alexander-move-judges-to-tears-sytycd-video/|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} ''The Star Ledger'' placed "Coming Home" at number three in its list of the top five routines performed during season eight.{{cite news|date=August 11, 2011|last=Hyman|first=Vicki|title='So You Think You Can Dance' finale: Top five routines of season eight|work=NJ.com|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/tv/index.ssf/2011/08/so_you_think_you_can_dance_fin_3.html|accessdate=August 23, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U9FvoS8?url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/tv/index.ssf/2011/08/so_you_think_you_can_dance_fin_3.html|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed another lyrical hip-hop routine "[[I Got You (Leona Lewis song)|I Got You]]" on the Top 16 performance episode. Celebuzz.com called the routine "dramatic and breathtaking".{{cite news|last=Ferguson|first=Wes|title=MUST WATCH: Emotional ‘So You Think You Can Dance’ Routine (VIDEO)|url=http://www.celebuzz.com/2011-06-30/must-watch-emotional-so-you-think-you-can-dance-routine-video|work=Celebuzz.com|date=July 1, 2011|accessdate=September 6, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ASpKqQSP?url=http://www.celebuzz.com/2011-06-30/must-watch-emotional-so-you-think-you-can-dance-routine-video/|archivedate=September 6, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} The dance generated positive reviews from the judges causing them to spontaneously kiss one another in response to a kiss that was choreographed into the dance. On the Top 8 performance episode, [[Lady Gaga]] appeared as a guest judge in which three hip-hop routines were performed. Although Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed two of them, she criticized their work while giving feedback on all three. She indirectly criticized them after a lyrical hip-hop piece choreographed by Marty Kudelka in which she referred to the dance style as "dated".{{cite episode|title=The Top 8 Perform|series=So You Think You Can Dance|serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (U.S. TV series)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]]|airdate=June 27, 2011|season=8|number=18}} Of the two routines they did choreograph, she criticized their use of props in both of them.{{cite web|first=Dennis|last=Ayers|title='So You Think You Can Dance' Recap - Lady Gaga No Fan of 'Nappy Tabs'|url=http://www.afterelton.com/tv/recaps/sytycd-lady-gaga-guest-judge-07-28-2011|work=AfterElton.com|date=July 28, 2011|accessdate=August 6, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U9UuIQc?url=http://www.afterelton.com/tv/recaps/sytycd-lady-gaga-guest-judge-07-28-2011|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} A flower was used in the first routine "[[Take a Bow (Rihanna song)|Take a Bow]]" about a cheating boyfriend asking for forgiveness. Several props including trash cans, rags, and brooms were used in the second routine "[[The Saga Continues...|Bad Boys for Life]]" about waste management workers. Aside from disliking the props, she described their hip-hop choreography for "Bad Boys for Life" as "[[wikt:contrived|contrived]]".{{cite web|date=July 27, 2011|first=Natalie|last=Finn|title=Live at So You Think You Can Dance: Lady Gaga Takes Over and Gets Carried Away (Literally!)|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/watch_with_kristin/live_you_think_you_can_dance_lady_gaga/254947|work=EOnline.com|accessdate=August 6, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62U9vdcsp?url=http://www.eonline.com/news/watch_with_kristin/live_you_think_you_can_dance_lady_gaga/254947|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite web|last=Yeo|first=Debra|date=July 28, 2011|title=So You Think You Can Dance: Going gaga for the girls|url=http://thestar.blogs.com/realitycheck/2011/07/so-you-think-you-can-dance-going-gaga-for-the-girls.html|work=Toronto Star|accessdate=August 20, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62UAQTYUs?url=http://thestar.blogs.com/realitycheck/2011/07/so-you-think-you-can-dance-going-gaga-for-the-girls.html|archivedate=October 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} On the finale, "Coming Home" was not picked as a "Judges Favorite" but two other routines they choreographed, "I Got You" and "[[Break Ya Neck]]", were chosen instead by judges Nigel Lythgoe and Lil' C respectively.{{cite web|title=SYTYCD Season 8 Finale: America’s Favorite Dancer Is…|url=http://www.homorazzi.com/article/sytycd-season-8-finale-recap-melanie-moore-winner-sasha-mallory-runner-up|work=Homorazzi.com|date=August 12, 2011|accessdate=December 7, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CjvHna5z?url=http://www.homorazzi.com/article/sytycd-season-8-finale-recap-melanie-moore-winner-sasha-mallory-runner-up/|archivedate=December 7, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} ===''Make Your Move''=== {{See also|Make Your Move (film)#Reception}} ''Make Your Move'' was released in South Korea and the United States in April 2013. With the exception of a make-out scene the choreography was generally praised among critics. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' stated "Although the bit of bedroom footwork was more laugh-inducing than anything, some of the dancing really is spectacular. Scenes from the competing clubs include impressive choreography and gravity-defying moves."{{cite news|last=Merry|first=Stephanie|date=April 18, 2014|title='Make Your Move' movie review|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/make-your-move-movie-review/2014/04/16/9b3556e8-c4b4-11e3-b574-f8748871856a_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=April 27, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308082153/https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/make-your-move-movie-review/2014/04/16/9b3556e8-c4b4-11e3-b574-f8748871856a_story.html|archivedate=March 8, 2016}} KPopStarz.com wrote "The dance teams and performances are enough to dominate the scenes, and definitely deserve a look. They bring forth the unique charm of watching a dance movie."{{cite web|date=April 12, 2014|title=BoA ‘Make Your Move’ - Her Dancing Is Fantastic!|url=http://www.kpopstarz.com/articles/87703/20140412/boa-make-your-move-her-dancing-is-fantastic.htm|work=KPopStarz.com|accessdate=April 27, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055839/http://www.kpopstarz.com/articles/87703/20140412/boa-make-your-move-her-dancing-is-fantastic.htm |archivedate=March 4, 2016}} [[RogerEbert.com]] stated "'Make Your Move' rests on the success of its various dance sequences, not its plot. And the dancing here is exciting, innovative, and specific. Each 'number' has a story behind it, a motivation, a different look and feel... I could have lived without the choreographed (literally) foreplay scene, as they dance their way to the bed, but there are other dance sequences between the two where their chemistry vibrates off the screen."{{cite web|last=O'Malley|first=Sheila|date=April 18, 2014|title=Make Your Move Movie Review & Film Summary|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/make-your-move-2014|work=RogerEbert.com |accessdate=April 27, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508075836/http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/make-your-move-2014|archivedate=May 8, 2016}} ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' said "The Romeo and Juliet-inspired plotline basically serves as a framing device allowing the opportunity for a plethora of exuberant dance sequences that particularly show off Hough's considerable talent."{{cite news|last=Scheck|first=Frank|date=April 17, 2014|title=Make Your Move: Film Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/make-your-move-film-review-697237|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=April 27, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160223142843/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/make-your-move-film-review-697237|archivedate=February 23, 2016}} ==Awards and recognition== '''Primetime Emmy Awards'''
Tabitha and Napoleon have won two Emmys from a total of four nominations. At the 2013 Primetime Emmy Awards ceremony, they joined the other choreography nominees and created a routine honoring dance that was performed just before the Outstanding Choreography award was presented. 2013 was the first year the Outstanding Choreography award was presented at the Primetime Emmys telecast rather than at the [[Primetime Emmy Award#Creative Arts Primetime Emmys|Creative Arts Emmy]]s ceremony which takes place a week prior.{{cite news|last=Garron|first=Barry|date=September 20, 2013|title=Breaking Bad, Modern Family Are Top Shows at 65th Primetime Emmys|url=http://www.emmys.com/news/awards-news/65th-primetime-emmys-wrap|work=Emmys.com|accessdate=September 28, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201205023/http://www.emmys.com/news/awards-news/65th-primetime-emmys-wrap|archivedate=February 1, 2014}} {| class="wikitable" width=50% |- !Year !Award {| class="wikitable" width=50% |- !Year !Award !Result |- | style="text-align:center;"|2017 |Best Live Show of the Year |{{won}}{{cite web|title=2017 Nominees List|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B6qcwXq2Uh8IOWp1Q01PTVlVdUk/view|accessdate=February 28, 2017}} |- | style="text-align:center;"|2017 |Best Live Performance on Television |{{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;"|2012 | Decade of Dance | {{won}}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldofdance.com/2012/02/22/wod-2012-industry-awards-decade-of-dance-nappytabs/|title=WOD 2012 Industry Awards: Decade of Dance – Nappytabs|date=February 22, 2012|work=WorldOfDance.com|accessdate=February 25, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65iHdfWBH?url=http://www.worldofdance.com/2012/02/22/wod-2012-industry-awards-decade-of-dance-nappytabs/|archivedate=February 25, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} |} '''Entertainment Weekly'''
In 2011, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' compiled a list of the "25 Best Performances Ever" on ''So You Think You Can Dance''. Tabitha and Napoleon choreographed four routines on the list.Sources: *For "Outta Your Mind", see: {{cite web|title='So You Think You Can Dance': 25 Best Performances Ever - Photo 25 of 25|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20389677_20502439_20974218,00.html|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=June 15, 2011|accessdate=July 4, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zvcDpa11?url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20389677_20502439_20974218,00.html|archivedate=July 4, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=}} *For "No Air", see: {{cite web|title='So You Think You Can Dance': 25 Best Performances Ever - Photo 24 of 25|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20389677_20502439_20974217,00.html#20974217|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=June 15, 2011|accessdate=October 21, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715052821/http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20389677_20502439_20974217,00.html#20974217|archivedate=July 15, 2014}} *For "Bleeding Love", see: {{cite web|title='So You Think You Can Dance': 25 Best Performances Ever - Photo 15 of 25|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20389677_20502439_20974217,00.html#20974206|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=June 15, 2011|accessdate=October 21, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026022832/http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20389677_20502439_20974217,00.html|archivedate=October 26, 2012}} *For "My Chick Bad", see: {{cite web|title='So You Think You Can Dance': 25 Best Performances Ever - Photo 3 of 25|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20389677_20502439_20974217,00.html#20974187|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=June 15, 2011|accessdate=October 21, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026022832/http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20389677_20502439_20974217,00.html|archivedate=October 26, 2012}} {| class="wikitable" width=50% |- !Year !Work !Rank |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="4"|2011 | "Outta Your Mind" | style="text-align:center; background:#B0C4DE" | #1 |- | "No Air" | style="text-align:center; background:#B0C4DE" | #2 |- | "Bleeding Love" | style="text-align:center; background:#B0C4DE" | #11 |- | "My Chick Bad" | style="text-align:center; background:#B0C4DE" |#23 |} ==Charity work== Tabitha and Napoleon have donated money and their time to different non-profit organizations. In 2009, they made an appearance at the Life Changing Lives Gala, the proceeds of which benefited the [[Wounded Warrior Project]], the [[Make-A-Wish Foundation]], and the [[Boys & Girls Clubs of America|Boys & Girls Clubs]]. At the event, dancers Katie Shean and Joshua Allen from season four of ''So You Think You Can Dance'' performed the D'umo choreographed "No Air" lyrical hip-hop routine about a soldier telling his girlfriend he is being deployed.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywire.com/uncategorized/life-changing-lives-gala-to-feature-live-performances|title=Life Changing Live's Gala To Feature Live Performances|date=September 1, 2009|work=Hollywire.com|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rZDssSi4?url=http://www.hollywire.com/uncategorized/life-changing-lives-gala-to-feature-live-performances|archivedate=July 28, 2010|accessdate=July 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} In the wake of the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]], Tabitha and Napoleon held a week-long fundraiser from online sales of their dancewear line.{{cite web|url=http://community.intellicontact.com/p/nappytabs/newsletters/shoponline/posts/nappytabs-fundraiser-for-haiti|title=Nappytabs Fundraiser for Haiti|work=IntelliContact.com|date=January 23, 2010|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPQ3?url=http://community.intellicontact.com/p/nappytabs/newsletters/shoponline/posts/nappytabs-fundraiser-for-haiti|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} The money raised was donated to Artists for Peace and Justice who in turn gave 100% of their donations toward humanitarian relief efforts.{{cite web|url=http://artistsforpeaceandjustice.com/events.html|title=Support for APJ|work=ArtistsForPeaceAndJustice.com|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qybBFp18?url=http://artistsforpeaceandjustice.com/events.html|archivedate=July 4, 2010|accessdate=July 4, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} For a separate fundraiser, they donated Nappytabs merchandise for a silent auction held by the organization Art4Life to benefit the [[American Cancer Society]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pollstar.com/blogs/news/archive/2010/05/20/723896.aspx|title=Art4Life Strikes "Glee" Gold|date=May 20, 2010|work=Pollstar.com|accessdate=July 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sJzuOPQC?url=http://www.pollstar.com/blogs/news/archive/2010/05/20/723896.aspx|archivedate=August 28, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=}} In 2012, they taught classes at "The JabbaWockeez Experience" held at the Alexis Park Resort in Las Vegas. The event raised money for the Monsters on the Move Foundation which grants scholarships to aspiring dancers.{{cite web|title=Monsters Teams Up with JabbaWockeez for Las Vegas Dance Event|url=http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2012/02/monsters-teams-up-with-jabbawockeez-for-las-vegas-dance-event|work=Dance Studio Life|accessdate=February 12, 2012|date=February 2, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/669aOHwPO?url=http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2012/02/monsters-teams-up-with-jabbawockeez-for-las-vegas-dance-event/|archivedate=March 14, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} In 2013, they worked with the Jabbawockeez again on a music video to the song "Celebrate" by [[Empire of the Sun (band)|Empire of the Sun]] and [[Tommy Trash]]. The music video also featured [[Les Twins]], [[8 Flavahz]], and [[Harry Shum, Jr.]] and was used to raise money for a Coke [[(RED)]] campaign to decrease the number of HIV-infected newborns and raise awareness about AIDS.{{cite press release|date=October 31, 2013|title=Coca-Cola and (RED) Join Forces to Inspire People to Move for the Movement to Help Deliver an AIDS-Free Generation|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20131031005895/en/Coca-Cola-RED-Join-Forces-Inspire-People-Move|publisher=Business Wire|accessdate=November 10, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110082146/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20131031005895/en/Coca-Cola-RED-Join-Forces-Inspire-People-Move|archivedate=November 10, 2013}} For [[Veterans Day]] 2013, they choreographed a military themed performance for the Homeward Bound Telethon that aired live on the [[Military Channel]]. The purpose of the [[telethon]] was to raise money for veterans who suffer from [[traumatic brain injury|TBI]] and [[PTSD]].{{cite news|last=Hayer|first=Melissa|date=October 25, 2013|url=http://newsok.com/homeward-bound-telethon-to-air-nov.-10-on-military-channel/article/3897538|title=Homeward Bound Telethon to air Nov. 10 on Military Channel|work=[[NewsOK]]}} Tabitha and Napoleon are on the board of directors of the Dizzy Feet Foundation and the [[advisory board]] of The Young Choreographers Festival.Sources: *For Dizzy Feet, see {{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://dizzyfeetfoundation.org/about-us|work=DizzyFeetFoundation.org|accessdate=May 12, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130513211504/http://dizzyfeetfoundation.org/about-us|archivedate=May 13, 2013|df=}} *For Young Choreographers Festival, see {{cite web|title=Lineup Announced for Young Choreographers’ Festival|url=http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2011/03/lineup-announced-for-young-choreographers%E2%80%99-festival|work=Dance Studio Life|accessdate=March 14, 2012|date=March 23, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/669bCKeHG?url=http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2011/03/lineup-announced-for-young-choreographers%E2%80%99-festival/|archivedate=March 14, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}} ==See also== {{Portal|Biography|Dance}} *[[List of dance personalities]] *[[List of dancers]] ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==External links== {{wikiquotepar|Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo}} *{{Facebook User|id=Nappytabs/32552994585|name=Nappytabs}} *{{Instagram|id=Nappytabs|name=Nappytabs}} *{{YouTube|show=nappytabs1|Nappytabs +1}} {{Hip-hop dance}} {{America's Best Dance Crew}} Hastings,
New Zealand | coordinates = {{coord|39|38|09|S|176|50|45|E|type:edu_region:NZ-HKB|display=inline,title}} | principal = Pippa Caccioppoli | roll = {{NZ school roll data|231|y||y}} ({{NZ school roll data|||y}}) | decile = 6N{{cite web |url= http://www.minedu.govt.nz/~/media/MinEdu/Files/EducationSectors/PrimarySecondary/SchoolOpsResourcing/OperationalFundingDeciles/DecileChanges_20142015.xls |title= Decile Change 2014 to 2015 for State & State Integrated Schools |publisher= Ministry of Education |accessdate= 12 February 2015}} | MOE = 231 | homepage = [http://www.taikurasteiner.school.nz/ www.taikurasteiner.school.nz] }} '''Taikura Rudolf Steiner School''' is a co-educational state integrated composite school for students in Years 1 to 13, located in [[Hastings, New Zealand]]. ==Alumni== * [[Caroline Evers-Swindell]], gold-medal winning rower * [[Georgina Evers-Swindell]], gold-medal winning rower * [[Benjamin Crellin]], comedian ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.taikurasteiner.school.nz/}} {{Schools in Hawke's Bay}} [[Category:Secondary schools in New Zealand]] [[Category:Schools in Hastings, New Zealand]] [[Category:Waldorf schools in New Zealand]]

page.title: The State Hermitage Youth Education Center

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2017}} {{ref improve|date=April 2017}} '''The State Hermitage Youth Education Center''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Молодёжный образовательный центр Государственного Эрмитажа), is a [[contemporary art]] education program in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]] that is part of [[Hermitage Museum|The Hermitage Museum]]. The program is offered for all students, whether from St. Petersburg, other Russian cities or from abroad. Activities include lectures on the history and theory of art, exhibitions of contemporary art, [[Master class|masterclasses]], and access to Museum curators and collections.<ref>[http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/wps/portal/hermitage/learn/youth-center/?lng=en Official website of The Youth Center]</ref> There are also special semester programs for students studying from abroad. State Hermitage Youth Education Center organizes a number of international festivals and cultural programs on the history and traditions of different countries and nations.
== History == The Youth Center was launched in 2000 when Mijaíl Borisovich Piotrovsk, Director of The Hermitage, signed the order for the creation of the Student Club which bears the same name as the museum. Since 2011, it has been located in located in the east wing of Saint Petersburg’s [[General Staff Building (Saint Petersburg)|General Staff Building]], and since its founding it’s been supervised by curator Sofía Vladimirovna Kudryavtseva.
== Educational and cultural programs ==
=== Thematic sections === At the core of the Student Club are thematic sections, which are managed by museum staff. Membership is open to students or graduates from universities in Saint Petersburg or from those in the [[Leningrad Region|Leningrad region]]. Which thematic section they decide to join depends exclusively on their particular inclinations and interests. All activities at the Youth Center begin on October 1 – the day on which Russia celebrates “student day” in the [[Hermitage Theatre]].
=== Educational Programs ===
==== Present Art ==== The "Present Art" program includes masterclasses and exhibitions of renowned artists, meetings with curators of international art projects, lectures about current issues in contemporary art, discussions and seminars. These programs invite the participation of representatives from specific departments of Russian universities ([[St. Petersburg State University]], [[Herzen University]], I. Repin St.Petersburg State Academy Institute of painting, sculpture and architecture, Saint Petersburg Stieglitz State Academy of Art and Design).
==== Project “Hermitage 20/21” ==== This educational program includes meetings with curators of exhibitions, conferences and masterclasses conducted by artists. Recent programs for the exhibitions: * “[[Jake and Dinos Chapman]]: The end of fun” (in Russian: Конец веселья) * "[[Anthony Gormley]]: In all the growth" (in Russian: Во весь рост) * "[[Henry Moore]] in the Hermitage: Sculpture and drawing." * "[[Annie Leibovitz]]: The life of a photographer: 1990-2005 "(Russian: Жизнь фотографа: 1990-2005).
==== Museum and small museologists ==== On February 1, 2013 The Youth Center launched a new and unique program, "Museum and small museologist", thanks to the initiative of St. Petersburg State University’s Philosophy Department and approved by Director of The Hermitage. This program is directed to students 9 to 11 years old and strives to show them how a contemporary art museum works and what its employees do. During the academic year, the students meet with principal figures of the museum - the director, restorers, curators, for example - and thereby learn about the real work of different departments of the museum.
==== Let's meet the Yamal! ==== This program was developed by the Youth Center in collaboration with the [[Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug|Yamalo-Nenets]] Fraternity – members of the Student Club - to teach about the colorful history of this indigenous people. The program includes an exhibition of applied art, workshops, masterclasses, folk concerts and documentary film screenings.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/wps/portal/hermitage/learn/youth-center/?lng=en Official website]
[[Category:Hermitage Museum]] [[Category:Education in Saint Petersburg]] [[Category:Art education organizations]] {{DEFAULTSORT:State Hermitage Youth Education Center}}

{{Infobox video game |title = Toy Shop |image = Toy Shop.jpg |image_size = 256px |developer = Seed Studios |publisher=[[Majesco Entertainment]] [[Codemasters]] |producer = Filipe Pina |released = {{vgrelease|NA|April 29, 2008|EU|October 2, 2008}} |genre = [[Simulation video game|Simulation]], [[role-playing video game]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Nintendo DS]] }} '''''Toy Shop''''' is a [[Simulation video game|simulation]]/[[role-playing video game]] [[video game]] developed by Portuguese team Seed Studios and published by [[Majesco Entertainment]] for the [[Nintendo DS]] handheld video game console. It is often compared to the [[Story of Seasons (series)|Story of Seasons]] series but with a Toy Shop theme.
It was developed by the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[video game]]s company Seed Studios.
